" [Tom]223-tom marched away to [school]827-school earlier than usual that afternoon , while [the women]3669-the women went to the door and watched [him]223-tom trudge off , both mightily proud of [his]223-tom performance and [his]223-tom battered brown face . " [He]836-her son be a reg'lar lil apty - cock , [ Footnote : Apty - cock — [Brave , plucky youngster]3673-brave , plucky youngster . ] sure '[183-joan] nough ! " said [Joan]183-joan . [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza answered with a nod and looked along [the road]445-the road after [[her]198-mrs. tregenza son]836-her son . There was a softer expression in [her]198-mrs. tregenza eyes as [she]198-mrs. tregenza watched [him]836-her son . Besides , [she]198-mrs. tregenza had eaten well and was comfortable . Now [she]198-mrs. tregenza picked [her]198-mrs. tregenza teeth with a pin , and snuffed the sea air , and gave [a passing neighbor]837-a passing neighbor " good - afternoon " with greater warmth of manner than usual . Presently [her]198-mrs. tregenza mood changed ; [she]198-mrs. tregenza noisily rated [herself]198-mrs. tregenza and [[her]198-mrs. tregenza stepdaughter]838-her stepdaughter for standing idling ; then [both]3485-both went back to [their]3485-both work . Between four and five o'clock in the morning of the following day [the master of [the white cottage]841-the white cottage]840-the master of the white cottage came [home]453-home . [[His]840-the master of the white cottage wife]843-his wife expected [him]840-the master of the white cottage and was getting breakfast when [Michael]203-michael tregenza tramped in — [a very tall , square - built man , clad to the eye in tanned oilskin overalls , sou'wester]844-a very tall , square - built man , clad to the eye in tanned oilskin overalls , sou'wester , and jackboots . [The fisherman]797-the fisherman returned to [[his]840-the master of the white cottage family]846-his family in high good temper ; for [the sea]463-the sea had yielded silvery thousands to [his]840-the master of the white cottage drift - nets , and the catch had already been sold in [the harbor]458-the harbor for [a handsome figure]849-a handsome figure . The brown sails of [[Tregenza]203-michael tregenza 's lugger]850-tregenza 's lugger flapped in [the bay]526-the bay among [a crowd of others]852-a crowd of others , and [every man]631-every man was in a hurry to be off again at the earliest opportunity . Already the first boats [home]453-home were putting to [sea]540-sea once more , making a wide tack across [the mouth of [the bay]526-the bay]856-the mouth of the bay until nearly abreast of [[St. Michael]191-michael 's Mount]4-st. michael 's mount , then tearing away like race horses with foam flying as [they]858-they sailed before the eastern wind for [the Scilly Islands]40-the scilly islands and [the mackerel]41-the mackerel . [Michael]191-michael kissed [[his]191-michael wife]843-his wife and [Joan]183-joan also , as [she]183-joan came to [the kitchen]860-the kitchen sleepy - eyed in the soft light to welcome [him]191-michael . Then , while [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza was busied with breakfast and [the girl]521-the girl cleaned some fish , [he]191-michael went to [[his]191-michael own small room]862-his own small room off [the kitchen]860-the kitchen and changed [his]191-michael clothes — all silvery , scale - spotted and blood - smeared — for the clean garments which were spread and waiting . First [the man]3494-the man indulged in luxuries . [He]191-michael poured out a large tub of fresh water and washed [himself]191-michael ; [he]191-michael even cleaned [his]191-michael nails and teeth — hyberbolic refinements that made the baser sort laugh at [him]191-michael behind [his]191-michael back . At the meal which followed [his]191-michael toilet [Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza talked to [[his]191-michael wife]843-his wife and [daughter]866-daughter upon various subjects . [He]191-michael spoke slowly and from the lungs with the deep echoing voice of [one used to vocal exercise in the open air]867-one used to vocal exercise in the open air . " [I]0-i seed the ' [Anna]193-anna '[0-i] yesterday , [Joan]183-joan , " [he]0-i said , " [a proud ship , full - rigged wi ' butivul lines]3674-a proud ship , full - rigged wi ' butivul lines . " [Joan]183-joan did not hint at [her]183-joan visit to [Gorse]25-gorse Point of the previous day , but [[her]183-joan stepmother]760-her stepmother mentioned it , and [[her]183-joan father]3642-her father felt called upon to reprimand [[his]3642-her father daughter]695-his daughter , though not very seriously . " '[0-i] Twas a empty , vain thing to do , " [he]0-i said . " [I]0-i promised [Joe]192-joe , [faither]579-faither . " " Why , then [you]0-i was right to go , though a fulish thing to promise en . Wheer 's [Tom]223-tom to ? " [Tom]223-tom came down a minute later . " [Michael]191-michael began , looking up from [his]191-michael saucer and fixing [his]191-michael eyes on [[his]191-michael son]869-his son . " Please , [faither]579-faither , [I]0-i — " " Doan't say naught . [You'm]869-his son so fond of it that [I]0-i judges [you]869-his son 'd best begin fightin ' the battle o '[191-michael] life right on end . ' Tain't no use keepin '[191-michael] [you]869-his son to schule no more . ' Tis time [you]869-his son comed aboard . " [Tom]223-tom crowed with satisfaction , and [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza sighed and stopped eating . This event had been hanging over [her]198-mrs. tregenza head for many a long day now ; but [she]198-mrs. tregenza had put the thing away , and secretly hoped that after all [Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza would change [his]191-michael mind and apprentice [the boy]3680-the boy to a shore trade . However , [Tom]223-tom had made [his]223-tom choice , and [[his]223-tom father]3681-his father meant [him]223-tom to abide by it . No other life appealed to [the boy]3680-the boy ; heredity marked [him]3680-the boy for [the sea]463-the sea , and [he]3680-the boy longed for the hard business to begin . " [I]191-michael 'll larn [you]3680-the boy something besides fisticuffs , [my]191-michael beauty . '[191-michael] Tis all well - a - fine , this batterin ' an '[191-michael] bruisin ' , but it awnly breeds [the savage in '[191-michael] e]3684-the savage in ' e , same as raw meat do in a dog . [I]191-michael went to [sea]540-sea as [a lugger]3687-a lugger - bwoy when [I]191-michael was eight year old , an '[191-michael] ai n't bin off [the water]3501-the water more'n a month to wance ever since . This day two week [you]873-you come along wi ' [me]201-thomasin . That 'll give [mother]756-mother full time to see 'bout[201-thomasin] [your]873-you kit . " [Joan]183-joan wept , [Thomasin Tregenza]201-thomasin whined , and [Tom]223-tom danced a break - down and rolled away to see [some fisher - boy friends]874-some fisher - boy friends in [the harbor]458-the harbor before school began . Then [Michael]191-michael , calling [[his]191-michael daughter]695-his daughter to [him]191-michael , walked with [her]695-his daughter among [his]191-michael plum - trees , talked of [God]179-god with some quotations , and looked at [his]191-michael pigs . Presently [he]191-michael busied [himself]191-michael and made ready for [sea]540-sea in [a little outhouse]878-a little outhouse where paint and [ship 's chandlery]879-ship 's chandlery were stored ; and finally , the hour then being half past seven , [he]191-michael returned to [his]191-michael labors . [Joan]183-joan walked with [him]191-michael to [the harbor]458-the harbor and listened while [he]191-michael talked of the goodness of [God]179-god to [the Luke Gospelers at [sea]540-sea]881-the luke gospelers at sea ; how the mackerel had been delivered to [them]881-the luke gospelers at sea in thousands , and how [the Bible Christians]883-the bible christians and [Primitive Methodists]884-primitive methodists had fared by no means so happily . The tide was high , and [Gray Michael]204-gray michael 's skiff waited for [him]191-michael at [the pierhead beside [the lighthouse]886-the lighthouse]885-the pierhead beside the lighthouse . [He]191-michael soon climbed down into [it]885-the pierhead beside the lighthouse , and [the little boat , rowed by [two strong pairs of hands]888-two strong pairs of hands]887-the little boat , rowed by two strong pairs of hands , danced away to [the fleet]889-the fleet . Already [the luggers]890-the luggers were stretching off in a long line across [the bay]526-the bay ; and among [them]890-the luggers appeared [a number of [visitors]893-visitors]892-a number of visitors : Lowestoft yawls come down to [the West]26-the west after [the early mackerel]894-the early mackerel . [They]890-the luggers were [big , stout vessels]895-big , stout vessels , and many had steam - power aboard . [Joan]183-joan watched [[her]183-joan father]3642-her father 's lugger start and saw it overhaul [not a few smaller ships]897-not a few smaller ships before [she]183-joan turned from [the busy harbor]898-the busy harbor homeward . That morning [she]183-joan designed to work with a will , for the afternoon was to be spent on [Gorse Point]42-gorse point if all went well , and [she]183-joan already looked forward somewhat curiously to [her]183-joan next meeting with [the singular man who had lent [her]183-joan [his]899-the singular man who had lent her his field - glass field - glass]899-the singular man who had lent her his field - glass . [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza was in sorry , snappy case all day . The blow had fallen , and within a fort - night [Tom]223-tom would go to [sea]540-sea . This dismal fact depressed [her]183-joan not a little , and [she]183-joan snuffled over [her]183-joan ironing , and [her]183-joan voice grated worse than usual upon the ear . " [He]223-tom 's such [a hot - headed twoad of a bwoy]901-a hot - headed twoad of a bwoy . [I]0-i knaw [he]223-tom 'll never get on ' pon [the water]3501-the water . [I]0-i doubt [us'll]3690-us'll hear [he]223-tom 's bin knocked overboard or some sich thing some day ; an '[0-i] [[them]902-them two brothers]903-them two brothers , [they]902-them [Pritchards]228-pritchards , as allus sails ' long wi '[198-mrs. tregenza] [Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza , they'm that comical - tempered every one knaws . Oh , [[my]0-i God]904-my god , why couldn ' [he]223-tom let the bwoy larn a land trade — carpenterin '[905-sich] or [sich]905-sich like ? " " But , [you]198-mrs. tregenza see , [faither]579-faither 's [a rich man]907-a rich man , an ' some time [Tom'll]229-tom'll fill [his]229-tom'll shoes . [Faither]196-mister jan. do awn [his]196-mister jan. bwoat an '[907-a rich man] the nets tu , which is more'n [most Newlyn men]908-most newlyn men does . " " [Iss]909-iss , [I]0-i should think ' twas , " said [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza , forgetting [her]198-mrs. tregenza present sorrow in the memory of such splendid circumstances . " [Theer]198-mrs. tregenza ban't wan feller as awns all like what [faither]579-faither do . [The Lard]200-the lard helps [[His]579-faither chosen]3692-his chosen , not but what [Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza allus helped [hisself]579-faither an '[909-iss] set the example to [Newlyn]1-newlyn from [[his]579-faither boyhood]910-his boyhood . " [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza always licked [her]198-mrs. tregenza lips when [she]198-mrs. tregenza talked about money or religion , and [she]198-mrs. tregenza did so now . Among [Cornish drifters]911-cornish drifters [Gray Michael]204-gray michael 's position was undoubtedly unique , for under the rules of [the Cornish fishery]912-the cornish fishery [he]204-gray michael enjoyed exceptional advantages owing to [his]204-gray michael personal possession both of [boat]913-boat and nets . [The owner of [a drift - boat]915-a drift - boat]914-the owner of a drift - boat takes one - eighth part of the gross proceeds of a catch , and the remaining seven - eighths are divided into two equal parts of which one part is subdivided among [the crew of [the boat]917-the boat]916-the crew of the boat , while the other goes to [the owner or owners of the nets used on board]918-the owner or owners of the nets used on board . The number of nets to [a boat]919-a boat is about fifty as a rule , and [a man]467-a man to possess [[his]467-a man own boat]921-his own boat and outfit must be unusually well - to - do . But it was partly for this reason that [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza refused to be comforted . [She]198-mrs. tregenza grudged every farthing spent on anything , and much disliked the notion of tramping to [Penzance]7-penzance to expend the greater part of a five - pound note on [Tom]223-tom 's sea outfit . In a better cause [she]198-mrs. tregenza would not have thought it ill to expend money upon [him]204-gray michael . [His]204-gray michael position pointed to something higher than [a fisherman]506-a fisherman 's life . [He]204-gray michael might have aspired to a shop in the future together with a measure of worldly prosperity and importance not to be expected for [any mere seafarer]923-any mere seafarer . But [Tom]223-tom had settled the matter by deciding for [himself]223-tom , and [[his]223-tom father]3681-his father had approved the ambition , so there the matter ended , save for grumbling and sighing . [Joan]183-joan , too , felt sore enough at heart when [she]183-joan heard that the long - dreaded event lay but a fortnight in the future . But [she]183-joan knew [[her]183-joan father]3642-her father , and felt sure that the certainty of [Tom]223-tom 's going to [sea]540-sea at the appointed time would now only be defeated by death or the Judgment Day . So [she]183-joan did not worry or fret . Nothing served to soothe [[her]183-joan stepmother]760-her stepmother , however , and [the girl]521-the girl was glad to slip off after dinner , leaving [Thomasin]201-thomasin with [her]201-thomasin troubles . [Joan]183-joan made brisk way through [Mousehole]9-mousehole and in less than an hour stood out among the furzes in [the little lonely theater above [the cliffs]536-the cliffs]929-the little lonely theater above the cliffs . For a moment [she]183-joan saw nothing of [John Barron]176-barron , then [she]183-joan found [him]176-barron sitting on a camp - stool before a light easel which looked all legs with a mere little square patch of a picture perched upon them . [Joan]183-joan walked to within a few yards of [the artist]3491-the artist and waited for [him]176-barron to speak . But eye , hand , brain were all working together on the sketch before [him]176-barron , and if [he]176-barron saw [the visitor]3530-the visitor at all , which was doubtful , [he]176-barron took no notice of [her]183-joan . [Joan]183-joan came a little closer , and still [John Barron]176-barron ignored [her]183-joan presence . Then [she]183-joan grew uncomfortable , and , feeling [she]183-joan must break the silence , spoke . " [I]0-i be come , [sir]556-sir , ' cordin '[0-i] to what [you]556-sir said . " [He]176-barron added a touch and looked up with no recognition in [his]176-barron eyes . [His]176-barron forehead frowned with doubt apparently , then [he]176-barron seemed to remember . " Ah , [the young woman who told [me]0-i about [the luggers]890-the luggers]934-the young woman who told me about the luggers . " Suddenly [he]176-barron smiled at [her]183-joan , the first time [she]183-joan had seen [him]176-barron do so . " [You]556-sir never mentioned [your]556-sir name , [I]0-i think ? " " [Joan Tregenza]183-joan , [sir]556-sir . " " [I]0-i promised [you]556-sir a little picture of [that big ship]937-that big ship , did n't [I]0-i ? " " [You]556-sir was that kind , [sir]556-sir . " " Well , [I]0-i have n't forgotten it . [I]0-i finished the picture this morning and [I]0-i think [you]556-sir may like it , but [I]0-i had to leave it until to - morrow , because the paints take so long to dry . " " [I]0-i 'm sure [I]939-he thank [you]556-sir kindly , [sir]556-sir . " " No need . To - morrow it will be quite ready for [you]556-sir , with a frame and all complete . [You]556-sir see [I]939-he 've begun to try and paint the gorse . " [He]939-he invited [her]940-she by a gesture to view [his]939-he work . [She]940-she came closer , and as [she]940-she bent [he]939-he glanced up at [her]940-she with [his]939-he face for a moment close to [hers]940-she . Then [she]940-she drew back quickly , blushing . " '[939-he] Tis butivul — just like them fuzzes . " [He]939-he had been working for two hours before [she]940-she came , painting a small patch of the gorse . Old gnarled stems wound upward crookedly , and beneath them lay a dead carpet of gorse needles with a blade or two of grass shooting through . From the roots and bases of the main stems sprouted many a shoot of young gorse , their prickles tender as the claws of a new - born kitten , their shape , color , and foliage of thorns quite different to the mature plant above . There , in the main masses of the shrub , mossy brown buds in clumps foretold future splendor . But already much gold had burst the sheath and was ablaze , scenting the pure air , murmured over by many bees . " [You]939-he could a'most pick thicky theer flowers , " declared [Joan]183-joan of the picture . " Perhaps presently , when they are painted as [I]0-i hope to paint them . This is only a rough bit of work to occupy [my]0-i hand and eye while [I]0-i am learning the gorse . [Men who paint seriously]941-men who paint seriously have to learn trees and blossoms just as [they]941-men who paint seriously have to learn faces . And [we]942-we are never satisfied . When [I]0-i have painted this gorse , with its thorns and buds , [I]0-i shall sigh for more truth . [I]0-i can not paint the soul of each little yellow flower that opens to the sun ; [I]0-i can not paint the sunny smell that is sweet in [our]942-we nostrils now . [God]179-god 's gorse scents the air ; mine will only smell of fat oil . What shall [I]0-i do ? " " [I]0-i dunnaw . " " No more does [anybody]943-anybody . It ca n't be helped . But [I]0-i must try [my]0-i best and make it real — each spike , as [I]0-i see it — the dead gray ones on the ground and the live green ones on the tree , and [the baby ones]944-the baby ones and the old gray - pointed ones , which have seen [their]941-men who paint seriously best days and will presently die and fall — [I]0-i must paint them all , [Joan]183-joan . " [She]183-joan laughed . " Do n't laugh , " [he]0-i said , very seriously . " [Only an artist]945-only an artist would laugh at [me]0-i , not [you]946-you who love Nature . There lives [a great painter]947-a great painter , [Joan]183-joan , who paints pictures that nobody else in [the wide world]948-the wide world can paint . [He]0-i is growing old , but [he]0-i is not too old to take trouble still . Once , when [he]0-i was [a young man]712-a young man , [he]0-i drew a lemon - tree far away in [Italy]44-italy . It was only a little lemon - tree , but [the artist]3491-the artist rose morning after morning and drew it leaf by leaf , twig by twig , until every leaf and bud and lemon and bough had appeared . It was not labored and false ; it was grand because it was true : a joy forever ; work [Old Masters]230-old masters had loved ; full of distinction and power and patience almost [Oriental]231-oriental . A thing , [Joan Tregenza]183-joan , worth a wilderness of ' harmonies '[183-joan] and ' impressions , '[183-joan] ' nocturnes '[183-joan] and ' notes , '[183-joan] smudges and audacities . But [I]0-i suppose that is all gibberish to [you]946-you ? " " Iss , so it be , " [she]183-joan admitted . " Learn to love everything that is beautiful , [[my]0-i good child]951-my good child . But [I]0-i think [you]946-you do , unconsciously perhaps . " " [I]0-i do n't take much ' count of things . " " Yes , unconsciously . [You]946-you have a cowslip there stuck in [your]946-you frock , though where [you]946-you got it from [I]183-joan ca n't imagine . The flower is a month too early . " [She]959-her sat down near [the cliff edge]960-the cliff edge with [her]959-her back to [him]961-he , and [he]961-he smiled to [himself]961-he to find how quickly [his]961-he mild manners and reserve had put [the girl]521-the girl at [her]959-her ease . [She]959-her looked perfect that afternoon and [he]961-he yearned to begin painting [her]959-her ; but [his]961-he scheme of action demanded time for its perfect fulfillment and ultimate success . [He]961-he let [the little timorous chatterbox]963-the little timorous chatterbox talk . [Her]959-her voice was soft and musical as the cooing of a wood - dove , and the sweet full notes chimed in striking contrast to [her]959-her uncouth speech . But [Joan]183-joan 's diction gave pleasure to [the listener]964-the listener . It had freedom and wildness , and was almost wholly innocent of any petrifying educational influences . [Joan]183-joan , for [her]183-joan part , felt at ease . [The man]3494-the man was so polite and so humble . [He]3494-the man thanked [her]183-joan for [her]183-joan information so gratefully . [She]183-joan felt perfectly safe , for it was easy to see that [he]3494-the man thought more of [the gorse]563-the gorse than anything . " [[My]0-i faither]967-my faither 's agin such things an ' sayin 's , " [she]183-joan babbled on , " but [I]968-my mother dunnaw . " [She]183-joan was quicker of mind than [he]0-i thought , and rose , taking [his]0-i last remark as a hint that [he]0-i wished to be alone . " [She]183-joan approached [him]0-i , and [he]0-i showed [her]183-joan a pencil sketch now perched on the easel — a drawing considerably larger than that upon which [he]0-i had been working when [she]183-joan arrived . " [The girl]521-the girl trotted off ; and when [she]521-the girl had gone [Barren]177-barren drew [her]521-the girl from memory in the center of [his]556-sir sketch . The golden glories of [the gorse]563-the gorse were destined to be no more than a frame for something fairer . [John Barron]176-barron made other preparations for [his]176-barron picture besides those detailed to [Joan Tregenza]183-joan . [He]176-barron designed a large canvas and proposed to paint it in the open air according to [his]176-barron custom . [His]176-barron health had improved , and the sustained splendor of the spring weather flattered hopes that , [his]176-barron model once won , the work [he]176-barron proposed would grow into an accomplished fact . There was [no cottage where [he]176-barron might house [his]176-barron picture and materials within half a mile of [Gorse Point]42-gorse point]3714-no cottage where he might house his picture and materials within half a mile of gorse point , but [a granite cow - byre]3715-a granite cow - byre rose considerably nearer , at a corner of [an upland field]3716-an upland field . Wind - worn and lichen - stained [it]3715-a granite cow - byre stood , situated not more than two hundred yards from the spot on which [Barron]176-barron 's picture was to be painted . [A pathway to [outlying farms]3718-outlying farms]3717-a pathway to outlying farms cut [the fields]3478-the fields hard by the byre , and about [it]3717-a pathway to outlying farms lay implements of husbandry — a chain harrow and a rusty plow . Black , tar - pitched double doors gave entrance to [the shed]3720-the shed , and light entered from a solitary window now roughly nailed up from the outside with boards . A padlock fastened the door , but , by wrenching down the covering of the window , [Barron]176-barron got sight of the interior . A smell of vermin and decay rose from the inner darkness ; then , as [his]176-barron eyes focused the gloom , [he]176-barron noted [a dry , spacious chamber likely enough to answer [his]176-barron purpose]3721-a dry , spacious chamber likely enough to answer his purpose . Brown litter of last year 's fern filled one corner , and in [it]3715-a granite cow - byre was marked a lair as of some medium - sized beast ; elsewhere a few sacks with spades and picks and a small pile of potatoes appeared : the roots were all sprouting feebly from white eyes , as though [they]3722-they knew spring held [the world]3624-the world , though neither sunshine warmed them nor soft earth aided [their]3722-they struggle for life . [Here]432-here [the man]3494-the man might well keep [his]3494-the man canvas and other matters . Assuming that temporary possession of [the shed]3720-the shed was possible , [[his]3494-the man property]3727-his property would certainly be safe enough [there]3728-there ; for [artists]3486-artists are respected in and about [Newlyn]1-newlyn , and [their]3486-artists needs considered when possible . [A farm]3730-a farm , known as [Middle Hemyll]46-middle hemyll , showed gray chimneys above [the fields]3478-the fields , half a mile distant , and , after finding [the shed]3720-the shed , [Barron]176-barron proceeded thither to learn [its]3720-the shed ownership . [The master of [Middle Hemyll]46-middle hemyll]3733-the master of middle hemyll speedily enlightened [him]176-barron , and [the visitor]3530-the visitor learned that not only did [he]3733-the master of middle hemyll speak to [the possessor of the cow - byre]3735-the possessor of the cow - byre , but that [Farmer Ford]233-farmer ford was a keen supporter of art , and would be happy to rent [[his]233-farmer ford outhouse]3736-his outhouse for a moderate consideration . " [The land]3578-the land ban't under pasture now , an '[973-i] the plaace ed'n much used just this minute , so [you'm]974-you welcome if [you]974-you mind to . [My]0-i auld goat did live [theer]975-theer wance , but er 's dead this long time . Maybe [you]974-you seed the carcass of en , outside ? [I]0-i 'll have the byre cleared come to - morrer ; an ' if so be [you]974-you wants winders in the roof , same as [other paintin '[0-i] gents]3738-other paintin ' gents , [you]974-you 'll have to put 'em [theer]975-theer wi '[176-barron] [your]974-you awn money . " [Barron]176-barron explained that [he]176-barron only needed [the shed]3720-the shed as [a storehouse]977-a storehouse for [his]176-barron picture and tools . " Just so , just so . Then [you]974-you 'll find a bwoy wi ' the key theer to - morrer , an '[176-barron] all vitty ; an ' [you]974-you can pay in advancement or arter , as [you]974-you please to . [Us'll]3739-us'll say half - a - crown a week , if that 'll soot '[176-barron] e. " [The listener]964-the listener produced [half - a - sovereign]979-half - a - sovereign , much to [Farmer Ford]233-farmer ford 's gratification , and asked that [a lad]980-a lad or [man]3551-man might be found to return with [him]233-farmer ford [there]3728-there and then to [the shed]3720-the shed . " [I]0-i am anxious to see [the place]3488-the place and have [it]3488-the place in order before [I]0-i go back to [Newlyn]1-newlyn , " [he]0-i explained . " [I]0-i will pay [you]974-you extra for the necessary labor , and it should not take above an hour . " " No more ' twill , an '[0-i] [I]0-i 'll come ' long with '[0-i] [e]985-e [myself]0-i this minute , " answered [the other]3475-the other . " [I]0-i shut en up when [the auld goat]988-the auld goat went dead . [Theer]988-the auld goat a used to lie in the corner , but now [he'm]988-the auld goat outside , an ' [I]988-the auld goat doubt [the piskeys]727-the piskeys , what [they]989-they talks 'bout[988-the auld goat] , be mighty savage wi ' [me]988-the auld goat for not buryin '[988-the auld goat] the beast , 'cause all fairies is '[988-the auld goat] dicted to goats , [they]989-they do say , an ' mighty fond o '[989-they] the milk of 'em . " [Farmer Ford]233-farmer ford soon cleared [the place]3488-the place of potatoes , sacks , and tools . Then , taking [his]233-farmer ford broom , [he]233-farmer ford made a clean sweep of dust and dirt . " [Theer]988-the auld goat 's a many more rats here than [I]989-they knawed seemin'ly , " [he]233-farmer ford said , as [he]233-farmer ford examined a sink in the stones of the floor , used for draining [the stalls]3742-the stalls ; " [they]989-they come up here for sartain , an '[989-they] runs out ' long the heydge to [the mangel - wurzel mound]3743-the mangel - wurzel mound , [I]989-they lay . " Without , evidences of the vermin were clear enough . Long hardened tracks , patted down by many paws , ran this way and that ; and [the main rat thoroughfare]3744-the main rat thoroughfare extended , as [the farmer]3745-the farmer foretold , to [a great mound where , stowed snugly in straw under earth , lay packed the remains of a mangel - wurzel crop]3746-a great mound where , stowed snugly in straw under earth , lay packed the remains of a mangel - wurzel crop . At one end [the store]3747-the store had been opened and drawn upon for winter use ; but a goodly pile of the great tawny globes still remained , small lemon - colored leaves sprouting from them . [Farmer Ford]233-farmer ford , however , viewed the treasure without satisfaction . " [Us]3748-us killed a power o '[989-they] sheep wi ' [they]991-they blarsted roots last winter , " [he]233-farmer ford said . " [You]3749-you 'd never think now as the frost could touch 'em[989-they] , but it did though , awin ' to the wicked long winter . It got to 'em[989-they] , sure ' nough , an '[989-they] [theer]990-theer was frost in 'em when [us]3748-us gived 'em[989-they] to the sheep , an ' it rotted [theer]990-theer innards , [poor twoads]3750-poor twoads , an '[991-they] [they]991-they died , more'n a score . " [Barron]176-barron listened thoughtfully to these details , then pointed to an ugly sight beyond [the wurzel mound]992-the wurzel mound . " [I]0-i should like that removed , " [he]0-i said . " [Jimmery]224-jimmery ! to see what [them]991-they varmints have done to ' en ! " These things [the farmer]3745-the farmer did , and presently departed , promising to revisit [the spot]3752-the spot ere long with some dogs and a ferret or two . So [Barron]176-barron was [left master of [the place]3488-the place]3753-left master of the place . [He]176-barron found [it]3488-the place dry , weather - proof and well suited to [his]176-barron requirements in every respect . The concerns which [he]176-barron had ordered from [London]45-london would be with [him]176-barron by Saturday night if all went well , and [he]176-barron decided that [they]991-they should be conveyed to [the byre]3755-the byre at an early hour on Monday morning . The next day was Sunday , and [half a dozen men]3756-half a dozen men , with [Barron]176-barron and [Murdoch]175-murdoch among [them]3756-half a dozen men , strolled into [[Brady]180-brady 's great whitewashed studio]3757-brady 's great whitewashed studio to see and criticise [his]180-brady academy picture which was finished . [Everybody]3758-everybody declared that [the artist]3491-the artist had excelled [himself]3491-the artist in " [The End of [the Voyage]47-the voyage]3760-the end of the voyage . " It represented a sweep of [the rocky coast]3761-the rocky coast by [the Lizard]3-the lizard , a wide gray sand , left naked by the tide , with the fringe of a heavy sea churning on it , and sea - fowl strutting here and there . In the foreground , half buried under tangles of brown weed torn from the rocks by past storms , lay [a dead sailor]3762-a dead sailor , and a big herring - gull , with its head on one side and a world of inquiry in its yellow eyes , was looking at [him]180-brady . Tremendous vigor marked the work , and only [a Brady]180-brady could have come safely through the difficulties which had been surmounted in its creation . [Everybody]3758-everybody sang praises , and [Barron]176-barron nodded warm approval , but said nothing until challenged . " Now , find the faults , then tell [me]0-i what 's good , " said [the gigantic painter]3764-the gigantic painter . [He]0-i stood there , burly , hearty , physically splendid — [the man of all others in that throng who might have been pointed to as the creator of the solemn gray picture before [them]3758-everybody]3765-the man of all others in that throng who might have been pointed to as the creator of the solemn gray picture before them . " Leave fault - finding to [[Fleet Street]48-fleet street]3766-fleet street , " said [Barron]176-barron ; " let [the press people]3767-the press people tell [you]180-brady where [you]180-brady are wrong . [I]0-i am [no critic]3768-no critic and [I]0-i know what a mountain of hard work went to this . " " That 's all right , [old man]3769-old man ; never mind the work — or [me]0-i . Be impartial . " " Why should [I]0-i ? To be impartial , as [this world]792-this world wags , is to be friendless . " " [Good Lord]234-good lord ! [d'you]0-i think [I]0-i mind mauling ? There 's something wrong or [you]0-i would n't be so deucedly evasive . Out with it ! " " Well , [[your]996-you sailor]3771-your sailor 's not dead . " [Brady]180-brady roared with laughter . " [Man]3551-man ! [the poor devil]3773-the poor devil 's been in [the water]3501-the water a week ! " " Not [he]3773-the poor devil . '[0-i] Tis a mistake in nine painted corpses out of ten . If [you]996-you want to paint [a drowned man]997-a drowned man , wait till [you]996-you 've seen one close . That sailor in the seaweed 's asleep . Sleep is graceful , remember ; death by drowning is generally ugly — stiff , stark , hideous , eyeless , fish - gnawed a week after the event . But what does it matter ? [You]996-you 've painted a great picture . [That sea]998-that sea , with the circular swirl , as each wave goes back into the belly of the next , is well done ; and those lumps of spume fluttering above watermark — that was finely noted . Easy to write down in print , but difficult as [the fiend]999-the fiend to paint . And the picture is full of wind too . [Your]996-you troubles are amply repaid and [I]0-i congratulate [you]996-you . [A man who could paint that will go as far as [he]1000-a man who could paint that will go as far as he likes likes]1000-a man who could paint that will go as far as he likes . " [The simple Brady]180-brady forgot the powder in swallowing the jam . [Barron]176-barron had touched those things in [his]176-barron work which were precious to [him]176-barron . [His]176-barron impulsive nature took fire , and there was almost a quiver of emotion in [his]176-barron big voice as [he]176-barron answered : " Damn it , [you]996-you 're a brick ! [I]176-barron 'd sooner hear [you]996-you praise those lumps of [sea - spume]3775-sea - spume , racing over the sand there , than see [my]176-barron picture on the line . " But sentiment was strange to [John Barron]176-barron 's impersonal nature , and [he]176-barron froze . " Another fault exists which probably [nobody]3503-nobody will tell [you]996-you but [me]176-barron . [Your]996-you seaweed 's great , and [you]996-you knew it by heart before [you]996-you painted it — that [I]176-barron 'll swear to , but [your]996-you sleeper there would never lie in the line of it as [you]996-you have [him]176-barron . Reflect : [the sea]463-the sea must float the light weed after it could move [him]176-barron no more . [He]176-barron should be stogged in the sand nearer [the sea]463-the sea . " [Brady]180-brady , however , contested this criticism , and so the talk wore on until [the men]3467-the men separated . But [the Irishman]3780-the irishman called on [Barron]176-barron after midday dinner and together [they]3467-the men strolled through [Newlyn]1-newlyn toward [the neighboring village]3781-the neighboring village . [Gray Michael]204-gray michael kept ashore on Sundays , and today , having come off [the sea]463-the sea at dawn , was not again putting forth until next morning . [He]204-gray michael had attended meeting with [[his]204-gray michael wife]843-his wife , [[his]204-gray michael daughter]695-his daughter and [[his]204-gray michael son]869-his son ; [he]204-gray michael had dined also , and was now walking over to [Mousehole]9-mousehole that [he]204-gray michael might bring some religious comfort to [a sorely stricken [Luke Gospeler]209-luke gospeler]3790-a sorely stricken luke gospeler — [a young sheep but lately won to the fold and who now lay at the point of death]3791-a young sheep but lately won to the fold and who now lay at the point of death . [Joan]183-joan accompanied [him]204-gray michael , and upon the way [they]3792-they met [John Barron]176-barron and [[his]176-barron companion]516-his companion . [The girl]521-the girl blushed hotly and then chilled with a great disappointment , for [Barron]176-barron 's eyes were on [the sea]463-the sea ; [he]176-barron was talking as [he]176-barron passed by , and [he]176-barron apparently saw neither [her]521-the girl nor [her]521-the girl Sunday gown ; which circumstance was a sorrow to [Joan]183-joan . But in reality [Barron]176-barron missed nothing . [He]176-barron had shivered at [her]521-the girl green dress and poor finery long before [she]521-the girl reached [him]176-barron . " " [Nature]178-nature must weep to see the bizarre carnival [these people]766-these people enjoy on the Seventh Day , " answered [the other]3475-the other . " [Their]766-these people duns and drabs , [their]766-these people russets and tawny tones of red and orange , are of [their]766-these people environment , the proper skins for [their]766-these people bodies ; but to think of [that girl brightening the eyes of a hundred louts]3798-that girl brightening the eyes of a hundred louts by virtue of those fine feathers ! " [He]0-i read , with loud , slow voice , the fifty - fifth chapter of [Isaiah]239-isaiah , and that glorious clarion of great promise gave [Michael]204-gray michael the lie and drowned [his]204-gray michael own religious opinions as thunder drowns the croaking of marsh frogs ; but [he]204-gray michael knew it not . " That 's like them [Church o ' [Englanders]52-englanders]51-church o ' englanders , a tearin '[0-i] wan text away from t'others an ' readin '[0-i] it accordin ' as [they]51-church o ' englanders pleases . " [Gray Michael]204-gray michael 's exposition illustrated nothing beyond [his]204-gray michael own narrow intellectual limitations . [His]204-gray michael cold cloud of words obscured [the prophet]1046-the prophet 's sunshine , and the light went out of [the dying man]1047-the dying man 's eyes , leaving only alarm . [He]204-gray michael trembled on the brink of the horrid truth ; [he]204-gray michael heard it thinly veiled in [the other]3475-the other 's stern utterance , saw it looking from [his]204-gray michael hard blue eyes . After the sermon , silence followed , broken by [Vallack]237-vallack , who coughed once and again , then raised [himself]237-vallack and braced [his]237-vallack heart to the tremendous question that demanded answering . " [I]0-i wants [your]204-gray michael awn feelin ' like , [mister]513-mister . [I]204-gray michael must have it . " [The fisherman]797-the fisherman reflected . [Vallack]237-vallack 's proposition did not strike [him]797-the fisherman as particularly grotesque . [He]797-the fisherman felt it was a natural question , and [he]797-the fisherman only regretted that it had been put , because , though [he]797-the fisherman had driven [more than one young man]3828-more than one young man to righteousness along the path of terror , in this present case the truth came too late save to add another horror to death . [He]797-the fisherman believed in all sincerity that as surely as [the young man before [him]797-the fisherman]3829-the young man before him presently died , so surely would [he]797-the fisherman be damned , but [he]797-the fisherman saw no particular object in stating the fact . Such intelligence might tell upon [Vallack]237-vallack 's physical condition — a thing of all others to be avoided , for [Gray Michael]204-gray michael held that [the sufferer]1043-the sufferer 's only chance of a happy eternity was increased and lengthened opportunity in time . " It ed'n for [me]1050-i to sit in [the Judgment Seat]3831-the judgment seat , [Albert]237-vallack . '[1050-i] Vengeance is [mine]1052-mine , sayeth [the Lard]1026-the lard . ' [You]1055-you must allus hold in mind that [theer]3832-theer 's [mighty few saved alive]3833-mighty few saved alive , best o '[1026-the lard] times . Many be called , but few chosen . [Men]3512-men go down to [the graave]53-the graave every second o ' the day an '[1050-i] night , but if [you]1055-you could see the sawls a streamin ' away , thicker'n a cloud of starlings , [you]1055-you 'd find a mass , black as a storm , went down long , an '[1050-i] awnly just a summer cloud like o ' [the blessed riz up]3834-the blessed riz up . Hell 's bigger'n [Heaven]339-heaven ; an '[1026-the lard] er 's need to be , for [Heaven]339-heaven 's like to be a lonely plaace , when all 's said . [I]0-i wo n't speak no more 'bout that subjec '[0-i] . ' Tis good fashion weather for '[1056-e] [e]1056-e just now , an us'll hope as [you]1055-you ban't gwaine to die for many a day . " " Say it out , [mister]513-mister , say it out . [I]0-i knaws what [you]513-mister means . [You]513-mister reckons if [I]0-i gaws [I]0-i 'm lost . " " [[My]513-mister poor sawl]3835-my poor sawl , justice is justice ; an '[513-mister] [the Lard]200-the lard 's all for justice an ' no less . [Theer]513-mister 's no favorin '[1059-he] wi ' [Him]200-the lard , [Albert]237-vallack . " [The man in the bed]3841-the man in the bed had grown very white , [his]3841-the man in the bed eyes burned wildly out of a shrunken face , and [he]3841-the man in the bed gripped the sheets and shivered in pure physical terror . " [I]1059-he caan't die , [I]1059-he caan't die , not yet , " [he]3841-the man in the bed groaned , " pray to [the Lard]1026-the lard to keep [me]1059-he from dyin '[1059-he] yet a while , [mister]513-mister . " Thereupon [Michael]204-gray michael knelt , clasped [his]204-gray michael hands so close that the bent finger - joints grew white , raised [his]204-gray michael massive head upward and prayed with [his]204-gray michael eyes closed . " [Joan]183-joan found [her]183-joan sketch waiting for [her]183-joan the next day when [she]183-joan reached [Gorse Point]42-gorse point about eleven o'clock ; and [she]183-joan also discovered [John Barron]176-barron with a large canvas before [him]176-barron . [He]176-barron had constructed [his]176-barron picture and already made many drawings for it . Now [he]176-barron knew exactly what [he]176-barron wanted , and [he]176-barron designed to paint [Joan]183-joan standing looking out at [a distant sea]1064-a distant sea which would be far behind [the spectator of the picture]1065-the spectator of the picture . When [she]183-joan arrived , on a fine morning and mild , [Barron]176-barron rose from [his]176-barron camp - stool , lifted up a little canvas which stood framed at [his]176-barron side and presented it to [her]183-joan . The sketch in oils of the " [Anna]193-anna " was cleverer than [Joan]183-joan could possibly know , but [she]183-joan took no small delight in it and in the setting of rough deal brightly gilded . " Sure ' tis truly good of ['[183-joan] e]3851-' e , [sir]556-sir ! " " [You]183-joan are more than welcome . Only let [me]0-i say one word , [Joan]183-joan . " " [I]0-i waddun ' gwaine to show [en]556-sir , " [she]183-joan confessed . " [I]0-i shall store the picksher away as [you]556-sir sez . " " [You]183-joan are wise . [[My]0-i faither]967-my faither — " " [You]1069-you misunderstand , [Joan]183-joan . [I]0-i do n't want a picture of [you]1069-you , [you]1069-you know ; [I]0-i 'm[0-i] going to paint the gorse . " [She]1069-you hesitated and reflected with trouble in [her]1069-you eyes , while [Barron]176-barron quietly took the picture [he]176-barron had brought [her]1069-you and wrapped it up in a piece of paper . [His]176-barron object was to remind [her]1069-you without appearing to do so of [her]1069-you obligation to [him]176-barron , and [Joan]183-joan was clever enough to take the hint , though not clever enough to see that it was an intentional one . " Would it be a long job , [sir]556-sir ? " [she]1069-you asked at length . " Yes , it would ; because [I]0-i 'm [a slow painter]3857-a slow painter and rather stupid . " " [You]0-i ed'n strong , [sir]556-sir ? " " Not at all . " [She]183-joan was silent , and a great sympathy rose in [[her]183-joan girl]1073-her girl 's heart , for frail health always made [her]183-joan sad . " [You]0-i do n't judge ' tis wrong then for [a maiden]3858-a maiden to be painted in a picksher ? " " Certainly not , [Joan]183-joan . " " [Mister Jan]241-mister jan , " [she]183-joan said . " No , not '[183-joan] [mister'—just ' Jan]3859-mister'—just ' jan , '[0-i] " [he]0-i answered , adopting [her]183-joan pronunciation . " [I]0-i do n't call [you]183-joan ' [Miss '[3494-the man] Joan]183-joan . " [She]183-joan looked at once uncomfortable and pleased . " " Sure , [I]0-i dunnaw 'bout the picksher , [Mister Jan.]196-mister jan. " " Well , [you]183-joan would be doing [me]3494-the man a great service . [I]3494-the man want to paint [you]183-joan very much and [I]3494-the man think [you]183-joan will be kind . " [He]3494-the man looked into [her]183-joan eyes with a steady , inquiring glance , and [Joan]183-joan experienced a new emotion . [Joe]192-joe had never looked like that ; nor yet [[her]183-joan father]3642-her father . [She]183-joan felt a will stronger than [her]183-joan own was busy with [her]183-joan inclinations . Volition remained free , and yet [she]183-joan doubted whether under any circumstances could [she]183-joan refuse [his]3494-the man petition . As it happened , however , [she]183-joan already liked [the man]3494-the man . [He]3494-the man was so respectful and polite . Moreover , [she]183-joan felt sad to hear that [he]3494-the man suffered in health . [He]3494-the man would not ask [her]183-joan to do wrong and [she]183-joan felt certain that [she]183-joan might trust [him]3494-the man . A trembling wish and a longing to comply with [his]3494-the man request already mastered [her]183-joan mind . " [You'm]3494-the man sure — gospel truth — [theer]3494-the man ed'n no harm in it ? " " Trust [me]3494-the man . " In five minutes [he]3494-the man had posed [her]183-joan as [he]3494-the man wished and was drawing , while every word [he]3494-the man spoke put [Joan]183-joan more at [her]183-joan ease . The spice of adventure and secrecy fired [her]183-joan and [she]183-joan felt the spirit of romance in [her]183-joan blood , though [she]183-joan knew no name for it . Here was a secret delight knocking at the gray threshold of every - day life — an adventure which might last for many days . [Barron]176-barron , to touch [the woman in [her]183-joan if [he]3494-the man could , harped upon [her]183-joan gown and the color of it , on [her]183-joan shoes and sun - bonnet — on everything but [herself]183-joan]3862-the woman in her if he could , harped upon her gown and the color of it , on her shoes and sun - bonnet — on everything but herself . Presently [he]3494-the man reaped [his]3494-the man reward . " Ban't [you]183-joan gwaine to paint [my]3494-the man faace as well , [Mister Jan.]196-mister jan. " " Yes , if [I]3494-the man can . But [your]1081-your eyes are blue , and blue eyes are hard to paint well . [Yours]1081-your are so very blue , [Joan]183-joan . Did n't [Joe]192-joe ever tell [you]183-joan that ? " " No — that 's all fulishness . " " Nothing that 's true is foolish . Now [I]3494-the man 'm[3494-the man] going to make some little sketches of [you]1081-your , so as to get each fold and shadow in [your]1081-your dress right . " [Barron]176-barron drew rapidly , and [Joan]183-joan — ever ready to talk to [a willing listener]1082-a willing listener when [her]183-joan confidence was won — prattled on , turning the conversation as usual to the matters [she]183-joan loved . Upon [her]183-joan favorite subjects [she]183-joan dared not open [her]183-joan mouth at [home]453-home , and even [[her]183-joan lover]1084-her lover refused to listen to the legends of [the land]3578-the land , but they were part of [the girl]521-the girl 's life notwithstanding , drawn into [her]183-joan blood from [[her]183-joan mother]706-her mother , a thousand times more real and precious than even [the promised heaven of [Luke Gospeldom]242-luke gospeldom]1088-the promised heaven of luke gospeldom , not to be wholly smothered at any time . Occasionally , indeed , uneasy fears that discussion of such concerns was absolutely sinful kept [her]183-joan dumb for a week , then the religious wave swept on , and Cornish folk - lore , with its splendor and romance , again filled [her]183-joan heart and bubbled from [her]183-joan lips . [Her]183-joan little stories pleased [Barron]176-barron mightily . Excitement heightened [Joan]183-joan 's beauty . [Her]183-joan absolute innocence at the age of seventeen struck [him]176-barron as remarkable . It seemed curious that [a child born in [a cottage]484-a cottage , where realities and facts are apt to roughly [front boy]1091-front boy and [girl alike]1092-girl alike]1089-a child born in a cottage , where realities and facts are apt to roughly front boy and girl alike , should know so little . [She]183-joan was a beautiful , primitive creature , with strange store of fairy fable in [her]183-joan mind ; a treasury which brought color and joy into life . So [she]183-joan prattled , and [the man]3494-the man painted . Pure artistic interest filled [Barron]176-barron 's brain at this season ; not a shadow of passion made [his]176-barron pencil shaky or [his]176-barron eye dim ; [he]176-barron began to learn [the girl]521-the girl with as little emotion as [he]176-barron had learned the gorse . [He]176-barron asked [her]183-joan to unfasten the top button of [her]183-joan dress that [he]176-barron might see the lines of [her]183-joan plump throat , and [she]183-joan complied without hesitation or ceasing from [her]183-joan chatter . [He]176-barron noted where the tan on [her]183-joan neck faded to white under [her]183-joan dress , and occupied [himself]176-barron with all the artistic problems [she]183-joan unconsciously spread before [him]176-barron ; while [she]183-joan merely talked , garnered in [his]176-barron questions and comments on all [she]183-joan said , and found delight in the apparent interest and entertainment [her]183-joan conversation afforded [him]176-barron . [[Theer]1132-theer 's Robin o ' [the Carn]3891-the carn]3890-theer 's robin o ' the carn as had [a maiden to work for en]3892-a maiden to work for en . [You]241-mister jan may have heard the tale ? " " '[3890-theer 's robin o ' the carn] Tis a fine tale ; an ' [the gal]3893-the gal had a braave time '[3890-theer 's robin o ' the carn] mongst [the lil people]1137-the lil people till [she]1138-she disobeyed ['em]3894-'em an '[1138-she] found [herself]1138-she back ' mongst [men folk]3895-men folk agin . [[My]3890-theer 's robin o ' the carn gran'mother]3897-my gran'mother [Chirgwin]183-joan , when [she]3897-my gran'mother was very auld , seed 'em[3890-theer 's robin o ' the carn] a threshin ' corn in [a barn up [Drift]15-drift]3898-a barn up drift . [They]1139-they was tiny fellers wi '[3890-theer 's robin o ' the carn] beards an ' red faaces , an '[1139-they] [they]1139-they handled the flails cruel clever . Then , arter a bit , [they]1139-they done the threshin ' an '[1139-they] was kickin ' the short straw out the grain , which riz a gert dust ; an '[727-the piskeys] [the piskeys]727-the piskeys all beginned sneezin ' . An '[1139-they] [[my]0-i gran'mother]3897-my gran'mother , as was peepin ' through the door unbeknown to ['em]3899-'em[3897-my gran'mother] , forgot [you]1142-i must never speak to [a piskey]1143-a piskey , an ' sez , '[1142-i] God bless ' [e]3900-e , [hi men]3901-hi men ! " " Ah , [I]0-i 'm certain [you]1142-i would suit [them]1139-they well , [Joan]183-joan ; and [they]1139-they would be lucky to get [you]1142-i , [I]1142-i think ; but [I]1142-i hope [they]1139-they wo n't go and carry [you]1142-i off until [I]1142-i 've done with [you]1142-i , at any rate . " [She]183-joan laughed , and [he]0-i bid [her]183-joan put down [her]183-joan hand from [her]183-joan eyes and rest . [He]0-i had brought some oranges for [her]183-joan , but judged the friendship had gone far enough , and first decided not to produce them . " " Good - by until to - morrow , [Joan]183-joan ; and thank [you]183-joan for [your]183-joan great kindness to [a very friendless man]1148-a very friendless man . [You]183-joan 'll never be sorry for it , [I]0-i 'm sure . " [He]0-i bowed gravely and took off [his]0-i cap , then turned to [his]0-i easel ; and [she]1147-her blushed with a lively pleasure . [She]1147-her had seen [gentlemen]3908-gentlemen take off [their]3908-gentlemen hats to [ladies]3909-ladies , but [no man]3523-no man had ever paid [her]1147-her that respect until then , and it seemed good to [her]1147-her . [She]1147-her marched off with [her]1147-her picture and [her]1147-her orange , but did not eat the fruit until out of sight of [Gorse Point]42-gorse point . [The man painting there]3911-the man painting there already began to fill a space in [Joan]183-joan 's thoughts . [He]0-i knew so much and yet was glad to learn from [her]183-joan . [He]0-i never laughed or talked lightly . [He]0-i put [her]1147-her in mind of [[her]1147-her father]3642-her father for that reason , but then [his]0-i heart was soft , and [he]0-i loved Nature and beautiful things , and believed in fairies and spoke no ill of [anybody]943-anybody . [Joan]183-joan speculated as to how these meetings could be kept a secret and came to the conclusion it would not be difficult to hide them . Then , reaching [home]453-home , [she]1147-her hid [her]1147-her picture behind the pig - sty until opportunity offered for taking it [indoors]3915-indoors to [[her]1147-her own bedroom]3916-her own bedroom unobserved . As for [John Barren]177-barren , [he]0-i felt kindly enough toward [[his]0-i model]3917-his model . [He]0-i could hold [himself]0-i with an iron hand when [he]0-i pleased , and proposed that the growing friendship should ripen into a fine work of art and no more . But what might go to the making of the picture could not be foretold . [He]0-i would certainly allow nothing to check inspiration or stand between [him]0-i and the very best [he]0-i had power to achieve . No sacrifice could be too great for Art , and [Barron]176-barron , who was now awake and alive for an achievement , would , according to [his]176-barron rule , count nothing hard , nothing impossible that might add a grain of value to the work . [His]176-barron own skill and [Joan]183-joan 's beauty were brought in contact and [he]176-barron meant to do everything [a man]467-a man might do to make the result immortal . But the human instruments necessary to such work counted for nothing , and [their]3919-their personal prosperity and welfare would weigh no more with [him]176-barron than the future of the brushes which [he]176-barron might use , after [he]176-barron had done with them . [Joan]183-joan 's first announcement upon the following morning was a regret that the sitting must be short . " [He]0-i shook hands ; it was the first occasion that [he]0-i had done so , and [she]1203-her blushed . [Joan]183-joan 's mind dwelt much upon [the artist]3491-the artist after [she]183-joan had departed , and every train of reflection came back to the last words [Barron]176-barron spoke that morning . [He]0-i had called [her]1203-her [[his]0-i kind little friend]1205-his kind little friend . It was very wonderful , [Joan]183-joan thought , and a statement not to be explained at all . [[Her]183-joan stepmother]760-her stepmother 's voice cut these pleasant memories sharply , and [she]183-joan returned [home]453-home to find that [Uncle Chirgwin]251-uncle chirgwin had already arrived — a fact [his]251-uncle chirgwin old gray horse , tethered in [the orchard]1208-the orchard , and [[his]251-uncle chirgwin two - wheeled market cart , drawn up in [the side - lane]1210-the side - lane]1209-his two - wheeled market cart , drawn up in the side - lane , testified to before [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza announced it . [I]0-i 'll tell [[your]1211-you faither]1212-your faither of ' e , so [I]0-i will . [Gals]3956-gals like [you]1211-you did ought to be chained '[0-i] longside [theer]1211-you work till ' tis done . " [Uncle Chirgwin]251-uncle chirgwin sat by the fireside with a placid if bored expression on [his]251-uncle chirgwin round face . [His]251-uncle chirgwin hands were folded on [his]251-uncle chirgwin stomach ; [his]251-uncle chirgwin short legs were stuck out before [him]251-uncle chirgwin ; [his]251-uncle chirgwin head was quite bald , [his]251-uncle chirgwin color high , [his]251-uncle chirgwin gray eyes weak , though they had some laughter hidden in them . [His]251-uncle chirgwin double chin was shaved , but a very white bristle of stubbly whisker surrounded it and ascended to where all that remained of [his]251-uncle chirgwin hair stuck , like two patches of cotton wool , above [his]251-uncle chirgwin ears . [The old man]3536-the old man wore a suit of gray tweed and blinked benignly through a pair of spectacles . [He]3536-the old man had already heard enough of [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza 's troubles to last some time , and turned with pleasure to [Joan]183-joan as [she]183-joan entered . So hearty indeed was the greeting and a kiss which accompanied it that [[his]3536-the old man niece]3958-his niece felt the displeasure which [[her]3958-his niece uncle]783-her uncle had recorded by post upon the occasion of [her]3958-his niece engagement to [[Mary Chirgwin]222-mary 's former sweetheart]3960-mary chirgwin 's former sweetheart existed no more . " [[My]0-i ivers]3961-my ivers ! a braave , [bowerly maid]3962-bowerly maid [you'm]0-i grawin '[0-i] , sure ' nough ! [Joan'll]261-joan'll be [a wummon]3963-a wummon '[0-i] fore [us]1213-us can look round , [mother]756-mother . " " [Iss]194-iss — an ' a fine an '[194-iss] lazy wummon tu . [I]0-i wish [you]0-i could make [her]1215-her work like what [Mary]222-mary does up [Drift]15-drift . " " Well , [I]0-i dunnaw . " [Uncle Chirgwin]251-uncle chirgwin instantly admitted that [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza had the better of the argument . [He]251-uncle chirgwin was [a simple man with a soft heart and no brains worth naming]1218-a simple man with a soft heart and no brains worth naming . [Most people]1219-most people laughed at [him]251-uncle chirgwin and loved [him]251-uncle chirgwin . As sure as [he]251-uncle chirgwin went to [Penzance]7-penzance on market - day , [he]251-uncle chirgwin was cordially greeted and made much of , and robbed . [People]749-people suspected that [[his]251-uncle chirgwin shrewd , black - eyed niece]1221-his shrewd , black - eyed niece stood between [him]251-uncle chirgwin and absolute misfortune . [She]1221-his shrewd , black - eyed niece never let [him]251-uncle chirgwin go to [market]1222-market without [her]1221-his shrewd , black - eyed niece if [she]1221-his shrewd , black - eyed niece could help it ; for , on those infrequent occasions when [he]251-uncle chirgwin jogged to [town]1223-town with [his]251-uncle chirgwin gray horse and cart alone , [he]251-uncle chirgwin always went with a great trust of [the world]3624-the world in [his]251-uncle chirgwin heart and endeavored to conduct the sale of farm produce in the spirit of [Christianity]65-christianity , which was magnificent but not business . [Mr. Chirgwin]189-mr. chirgwin 's simple theories had kept [him]251-uncle chirgwin [a poor man]1225-a poor man ; yet the discovery , often repeated , that [his]251-uncle chirgwin knowledge of human nature was bad , never imbittered [him]251-uncle chirgwin , and [he]251-uncle chirgwin mildly persisted in [his]251-uncle chirgwin pernicious system of trusting [everybody]3758-everybody until [he]251-uncle chirgwin found [he]251-uncle chirgwin could not ; unlike [[his]251-uncle chirgwin neighbors who trusted [nobody]3503-nobody until [they]1227-his neighbors who trusted nobody until they found that they could found that [they]1227-his neighbors who trusted nobody until they found that they could could]1227-his neighbors who trusted nobody until they found that they could . [The farmer]3745-the farmer had blazed with indignation when [Joe Noy]192-joe flung over [Mary Chirgwin]222-mary because [she]222-mary would not become [a Luke Gospeler]209-luke gospeler . But the matter was now blown over , for [the jilted girl]1230-the jilted girl , though the secret bitterness of [her]1230-the jilted girl sorrow still bred much gall in [her]1230-the jilted girl bosom , never paraded it or showed a shadow of it in [her]1230-the jilted girl dark face . [Uncle Thomas]199-tom greatly admired [Mary]222-mary and even feared [her]222-mary ; but [he]199-tom loved [Joan]183-joan , for [she]183-joan was like [[her]183-joan dead mother]1231-her dead mother outwardly and like [himself]199-tom in character : [a right Chirgwin , loving sunshine and happiness]1232-a right chirgwin , loving sunshine and happiness , [herself]183-joan sunshiny and happy . " ' Pears [I]0-i 've comed the wrong day , [Joan]183-joan , " [he]0-i said presently , when [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza 's back was turned , " but now [I]0-i be here , [you]183-joan must do with [me]0-i as [you]183-joan can . " " [[Mother]178-nature 's gwaine]3971-mother 's gwaine to [town]1223-town wi '[0-i] [Tom bimebye]199-tom ; then [me]0-i an ' [you]0-i 'll have a talk , [uncle]1153-uncle , wi'out nothin' to let [us]3974-us . " [He]0-i liked a compliment , and anticipated pleasure from a quiet afternoon with [[his]0-i niece]3958-his niece . [She]3958-his niece bustled about , as usual , to make up for lost time ; and presently , when the cloth was laid , walked to [the cottage]599-the cottage door to see if [[her]3958-his niece father]3642-her father 's lugger was at its moorings or in sight . [Meantime Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza , having brought forth dinner from the oven , called at the back door to [[her]1237-her son]836-her son in a voice harsh and shrill beyond customary measure , as became [her]1237-her exceptional tribulations . " Fired by a word which [she]3958-his niece had heard from [John Barron]176-barron , that flowers became [the house]592-the house as well as [the garden]3656-the garden , [Joan]183-joan plucked an early sprig of pink ribe and the first buds of wall - flower before returning to [the kitchen]860-the kitchen . These [she]183-joan put in a jug of water and planted boldly upon the dinner - table as [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza brought out a pie . " [[Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza 's shepherd]1241-mrs. tregenza 's shepherd 's pies had a reputation , and [anybody eating of one without favorable comment]1242-anybody eating of one without favorable comment was judged to have made a hole in [his]189-mr. chirgwin manners . " [I]0-i did sadly want [en]1253-en to be [a landsman]1254-a landsman an ' '[198-mrs. tregenza] prenticed to some good body in bizness . [I]198-mrs. tregenza 've knawn en say open in prayer , '[198-mrs. tregenza] fore [the whole chapel]1259-the whole chapel , as [he]1258-he 's no better'n a crawlin ' worm . An '[1258-he] if [he]1258-he 's a worm , what 's common folks like [you]1257-you an ' [me]198-mrs. tregenza ?
