" [Mr. Chirgwin]189-mr. chirgwin admitted [his]189-mr. chirgwin own ridiculous religious insignificance as contrasted with [Gray Michael]204-gray michael . Indeed the comparison , so little in [his]189-mr. chirgwin favor , amused [him]189-mr. chirgwin extremely . [He]189-mr. chirgwin sipped [his]189-mr. chirgwin brandy and water and enjoyed a treacle - pudding which followed the pie . Then , when [Joan]183-joan was clearing up and [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza had departed to prepare for [her]198-mrs. tregenza visit to [Penzance]7-penzance , [Uncle Thomas]199-tom began to puff out [his]199-tom cheeks , and blow , and frown , and look uneasily to the right and left — actions invariably performed when [he]199-tom contemplated certain monetary achievements of which [he]199-tom was only too fond . The sight of [Mary]222-mary 's eyes upon [him]199-tom had often killed such indiscretions in the bud , but [she]222-mary was not present just then , so , with further furtive glances , [he]199-tom brought out [his]199-tom purse , opened it , and found a half - sovereign which reposed alone in the splendor of a separate compartment . [Uncle Chirgwin]251-uncle chirgwin then beckoned to [Tom]199-tom , who had gone into [the garden]3656-the garden till [[his]199-tom mother]752-his mother should be ready to start . " Good speed to ' [e]199-tom , [bwoy]3989-bwoy , " [he]199-tom said , " an '[200-the lard] may [the Lard]200-the lard watch over ' [e]199-tom by [land]664-land an '[752-his mother] [sea]540-sea . Take [you]199-tom this lil piece o ' money to buy what [you]199-tom 've a mind to ; an '[752-his mother] knaw [you]199-tom 've got [a auld man]1263-a auld man 's blessin ' '[752-his mother] long wi ' it . " " [Mother]178-nature , " said [Tom]199-tom , a minute later , " [uncle]1153-uncle have gived [me]752-his mother a bit o '[752-his mother] gawld ! " [She]752-his mother took the coin from [him]199-tom and [her]752-his mother eyes rested on it lovingly while the outlines of [her]752-his mother face grew softer and [she]752-his mother moistened [her]752-his mother lips . " First gawld 's ever [I]0-i had , " commented [Tom]199-tom . " [You'm]0-i ' mazin '[199-tom] generous wi ' [your]0-i moneys , [uncle]1153-uncle , an '[199-tom] [I]0-i thank [']0-i [e]1264-e hearty for the bwoy . Mighty good of '[199-tom] [e]1264-e — so much money to wance , " said [Thomasin]201-thomasin , showing more gratification than [she]201-thomasin knew . " [I]0-i wants [en]1264-e to be thrifty , " answered [the old man]3536-the old man , very wisely . " [You]1264-e knaws how hard it is to teach [young people]1266-young people the worth o ' money . " " Ay , an '[3536-the old man] [some auld wans]1267-some auld wans ! Blest if [I]0-i doan't think [you]1264-e 'd give [your]1264-e head away if ' [e]1264-e could . But [I]1264-e 'll take this here half - suvrin '[1264-e] for [Tom]199-tom . ' Tis a nest - egg as [he]199-tom shall add to as [he]199-tom may . " [Tom]199-tom did not foresee this arrangement , and had something to say as [he]199-tom tramped off with [[his]199-tom mother]752-his mother to [town]1223-town ; but though [he]199-tom could do more with [her]752-his mother and get more out of [her]752-his mother than anybody else in [the world]3624-the world , money was a subject concerning which [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza always had [her]198-mrs. tregenza way . [She]198-mrs. tregenza understood it and loved it and allowed no interference from [anybody]943-anybody , [Michael]204-gray michael alone excepted . But [he]199-tom cared not much for money and was well content to let [[his]199-tom wife]843-his wife hold the purse ; yet when [he]199-tom did occasionally demand an account , it was always forthcoming to the uttermost farthing , and [he]199-tom fully believed what [other people]3998-other people told [him]199-tom that [Thomasin]201-thomasin could make a sixpenny - piece go further than [any other woman in [Newlyn]1-newlyn]3999-any other woman in newlyn . [Mother]756-mother and [son]4001-son presently departed ; while [Mr. Chirgwin]189-mr. chirgwin took off [his]189-mr. chirgwin coat , lighted [his]189-mr. chirgwin pipe , and walked with [Joan]183-joan round about [the orchard]1208-the orchard . [He]1268-he foretold great things for the plums , now in full flower ; [he]1268-he poked the pigs with [his]1268-he stick and spoke encouragingly of [their]4003-their future also . Then [he]1268-he discussed [Joan]183-joan 's prospects and gladdened [her]183-joan heart by telling [her]183-joan the past must be let alone and need never be reverted to again . " [Mary]222-mary 's gettin '[1268-he] over it tu , " [he]1268-he said , " least - ways [I]0-i think [she]1269-her is . [Her]1269-her knaws wheer to look for comfort , bless [her]1269-her . [Us]1270-us must all keep friendly for life 's not long enough to do ' nough good in , [I]1268-he allus says , let alone the doin' o '[1268-he] bad . " Then [he]1268-he discussed [Joe Noy]192-joe , and [Joan]183-joan was startled to find , when [she]183-joan came to think seriously upon the subject , that though but a week and three days had passed since [she]183-joan bid [[her]183-joan lover]1084-her lover " good - by , " yet the picture of [him]1268-he in [her]183-joan mind already grew a trifle dim , and the prospect of [his]1268-he absence for a year held not the least sorrow in it for [her]183-joan . Presently , after looking to [his]1268-he horse , [Uncle Thomas]199-tom hinted at forty winks , if the same would be quite convenient , and [Joan]183-joan , settling [him]1268-he with some approach to comfort upon a little horsehair sofa in [the parlor]1164-the parlor , turned [her]183-joan attention to the making of saffron cakes for tea . [John Barron]176-barron held strong theories about the importance of the mental condition when work was in hand . Once fairly engaged upon a picture , [he]176-barron painted very fast , labored without cessation , and separated [himself]176-barron as far as might be from every outside influence . No new interests were suffered to intrude upon [his]176-barron mind ; no distractions of any sort , intellectual or otherwise , were permitted to occupy even those leisure intervals which of necessity lay between the periods of [his]176-barron work . On the present occasion [he]176-barron merely fed and slept and dwelt solitary , shunning [society of every sort]1273-society of every sort and spending as little time in [Newlyn]1-newlyn as possible . Fortunately for [his]176-barron achievement the weather continued wonderfully fine and each successive day brought like conditions of sunshine and color , light and air . This circumstance enabled [him]176-barron to proceed rapidly , and another fact also contributed to progress ; the temperature kept high and the cow - byre , wherein [Barren]177-barren stored [his]176-barron implements and growing picture , proved so well - built and so snug withal that on more than one occasion [he]176-barron spent the entire night there . Sweet brown bracken filled [a manger]1274-a manger , and of this [he]176-barron pulled down sufficient quantities to make , with railway rugs , an ample bed . The outdoor life appeared to suit [his]176-barron health well ; some color had come to [his]176-barron pale cheeks ; [he]176-barron felt considerably stronger in body and mentally invigorated by the strain of work now upon [him]176-barron . But though [he]176-barron turned [his]176-barron back on [[his]176-barron fellow - men]1275-his fellow - men [they]1275-his fellow - men sought [him]176-barron out , and rumors at length grew to a certainty that [Barron]176-barron was busy painting [somewhere on [the cliffs beyond Mousehole]1277-the cliffs beyond mousehole]1276-somewhere on the cliffs beyond mousehole . [Everybody]266-everybody supposed [he]176-barron had abandoned [his]176-barron ambition to get a portrait of [Joan Tregenza]183-joan ; but [one man]1278-one man was in [his]176-barron confidence : [Edmund Murdoch]175-murdoch . [The young artist]1279-the young artist had been useful to [Barron]176-barron . On many occasions [he]176-barron tramped out from [Newlyn]1-newlyn with additions to the scanty larder kept at [the cow - byre]1280-the cow - byre . [He]176-barron would bring hard - boiled eggs , sandwiches , bottles of soda - water and whisky ; and once [he]176-barron arrived at six o'clock in the morning with [a pony cart]1281-a pony cart in which was a little oil stove . [Barron]176-barron had confided in [Murdoch]175-murdoch , but begged [he]176-barron would let it be known that [he]176-barron courted [no society for the present]1282-no society for the present . As the work grew [he]176-barron spent more and more time upon it . [He]176-barron explained to [[his]176-barron friend]494-his friend quite seriously that [he]176-barron was painting the gorse , but that [Joan Tregenza]183-joan had consented to fill a part of the picture — a statement which amused [the younger artist]3572-the younger artist not a little . " But the gorse is extraordinary , [I]0-i 'll admit . [You]176-barron must have worked without ceasing . [She]183-joan will be exquisite . Where shall [you]176-barron get the blue for [her]183-joan eyes ? " " Out of the sky and [the sea]463-the sea . " " Does [the girl]521-the girl inspire [you]176-barron [herself]521-the girl , [John]176-barron ? [I]0-i swear something has . This is going to be great . " " It 's going to be true , that 's all . No , [Joan]183-joan is [a dear child]1287-a dear child , but [her]183-joan body 's no more than a perfect casket to [a commonplace little soul]1288-a commonplace little soul . [She]183-joan talks a great deal and [I]0-i like nothing better than to listen ; for although what [she]183-joan says is naught , yet [her]183-joan manner of saying it does not lack charm . [Her]183-joan voice is wonderfully sweet — it comes from [her]183-joan throat like a wood - pigeon 's , and education has not ruined [her]183-joan diction . " " [She]183-joan 's as shy as any wood - pigeon , too — [we]1289-we all know that ; and [you]176-barron 've done a clever thing to tame [her]183-joan . " " God forbid that [I]0-i should tame [her]183-joan . [We]1289-we met and grew friendly as wild things both . [She]183-joan is [a child of Nature]1290-a child of nature , [her]183-joan mind is as pure as [the sea]463-the sea . Moreover , [Joan]183-joan walks saint - guided . Folklore and local twaddle does not appeal overmuch to [me]0-i , as [you]176-barron know , yet the stories drop prettily from [her]183-joan lips and [I]0-i find pleasure in listening . " [Murdoch]175-murdoch whistled . " By Jove ! [I]0-i never heard [you]176-barron so enthusiastic , so positive , so personally alive and awake and interested . Do n't fall in love with [the girl]521-the girl before [you]176-barron know it . " To this warning [Barron]176-barron made a curious reply . " Everything depends on [my]0-i picture . [You]176-barron know [my]0-i rule of life ; to sacrifice all things to mood . [I]0-i shall do so here . The best [I]0-i can do must be done whatever the cost . " A shadow almost sinister lay behind the utterance , yet [young Murdoch]175-murdoch could not fathom it . [Barren]177-barren spoke in [his]177-barren usual slow , unaffected tones , and painted all the time ; for the conversation took place on [Gorse Point]42-gorse point . " Not sure if [I]0-i quite understand [you]177-barren , [old man]3769-old man , " said [Murdoch]175-murdoch . " It does n't matter in the least if [you]177-barren do n't , [[my]0-i dear fellow]1294-my dear fellow . " [His]177-barren words were hardly civil , but the tone in which [Barren]177-barren spoke robbed the utterance of any offense . " All [you]176-barron need do , " [he]177-barren continued , " is to keep silent in the interests of art and of [Joan]183-joan . [I]0-i do n't want [her]183-joan precious visits to [me]0-i to get back to [[her]183-joan father]3642-her father 's ears or [they]1296-they will cease , and [I]0-i do n't wish to do [her]183-joan a bad turn in [[her]183-joan home]1297-her home , for [I]0-i owe [her]183-joan a great debt of gratitude . If [men]3512-men ask what [I]0-i 'm doing , lie to [them]3512-men and beg [them]3512-men not to disturb [me]3512-men , for the sake of Art . What a glint the east wind gives to color ! Yet this is hardly to be called an east wind , so soft and balmy does it keep . " " Well , [you]0-i seem to be the better for [your]0-i work , at any rate . [You]0-i 're[3512-men] getting absolutely fat . If [Newlyn]1-newlyn brings [you]0-i health as well as fame , [I]0-i hope [you]0-i 'll retract some of the many hard things [you]0-i have said about it . " " It has brought [me]0-i an interest , and for that at any rate [I]0-i am grateful . Good - by . [I]0-i shall probably come down to - night , despite the fact that [you]0-i have replenished [[my]0-i stores]1299-my stores so handsomely . " [Murdoch]175-murdoch started [homeward]1300-homeward and met [Joan Tregenza]183-joan upon the way . [She]183-joan had given [Barron]176-barron one further sitting after [Uncle Chirgwin]251-uncle chirgwin 's call at [Newlyn]1-newlyn , but since the last occasion , and for a period of two days , chance prevented [the girl]521-the girl from paying [him]176-barron another visit . Now [she]183-joan arrived , however , as early as half - past ten , and [Murdoch]175-murdoch , while [he]175-murdoch passed [her]183-joan on [the hill]533-the hill from [Mousehole]9-mousehole , envied [[his]175-murdoch friend]494-his friend the morning 's work before [him]175-murdoch . [Joan]183-joan was very hot and very apologetic upon [her]183-joan arrival . " [I]0-i began to fear [you]175-murdoch had forgotten [me]0-i , " [the artist]3491-the artist said , but [she]183-joan was loud in protestations to the contrary . " No , no , [Mister Jan.]196-mister jan. [I]0-i 've fretted 'bout not comin '[183-joan] up like anything ; ay , an ' [I]183-joan 've cried of a night 'cause[183-joan] [I]0-i thot [you]175-murdoch 'd be reckoning [I]0-i waddun comin ' no more . But '[183-joan] tweern't [my]0-i doin' no ways . " " [You]175-murdoch had n't forgotten [me]0-i ? " " Indeed an ' [I]175-murdoch had n't . An '[175-murdoch] [I]0-i 'd be sorrerful if [I]0-i thot [you]175-murdoch thot so . " [She]183-joan walked to the old position before the gorse and fell naturally into it , speaking the while . " Tis this way : [mother]756-mother 's been bad wi ' faace ache arter [[my]183-joan brother]3921-my brother [Tom]199-tom went to [sea]540-sea wi '[183-joan] [faither]579-faither . An ' [mother]756-mother grizzled an '[756-mother] worrited [herself]756-mother reg'lar ill an ' stopped in bed two days an '[756-mother] kep on whinin ' 'bout[756-mother] what [I]0-i was to do if [she]756-mother died ; cause [she]756-mother s'posed [she]756-mother was gwained to . But so soon as [Tom]199-tom comed off [his]199-tom first trip , [mother]756-mother cheered wonnerful , an ' riz up to see to en , an '[756-mother] hear tell 'bout how [he]199-tom fared on [the water]3501-the water . " " [Your]1308-you head a wee bit higher , [Joan]183-joan . Well , [I]756-mother 'm[756-mother] thankful to see [you]1308-you again . [I]0-i was getting very , very lonely , [I]0-i promise [you]1308-you . And the more [I]0-i thought about the picture the more unhappy [I]0-i became . There 's such a lot to do and only such a clumsy hand to do it . The better [I]0-i know [you]1308-you , [Joan]183-joan , the harder become the problems [you]1308-you set [me]0-i . How am [I]0-i going to get [your]1308-you soul looking out of [your]1308-you eyes , [d'you]1308-you think ? How am [I]0-i to make those who may see [my]0-i picture some day — years after [you]1308-you and [I]0-i are both dead and gone , [Joan]183-joan — fall in love with [you]1308-you ? " " [La]66-la ! [I]0-i dunnaw , [Mister Jan.]196-mister jan. " " Nor do [I.]0-i How shall [I]0-i make the picture so true that [generations unborn]1309-generations unborn will delight in the portrait and deem it great and fine ? " " [I]0-i dunnaw . " " And yet [you]183-joan deserve it , [Joan]183-joan , for [I]0-i do n't think [God]179-god ever made anything prettier . " [She]183-joan blushed and looked softly at [him]0-i , but took no alarm ; for though such a compliment had never before been paid [her]183-joan , yet , as [Barron]176-barron spoke the words , slowly , critically , without enthusiasm or any expression of pleasure on [his]176-barron face , they had little power to alarm . [He]176-barron merely stated what [he]176-barron seemed to regard as a fact . There was almost a suggestion of irritation in [his]176-barron utterance , as though [[his]176-barron model]3917-his model 's rare beauty only increased [his]176-barron own artistic difficulties ; and , perhaps fearing from [her]183-joan smile that [she]183-joan found undue pleasure in [his]176-barron statement , [he]176-barron added to it : " [I]0-i do n't say that to natter [you]183-joan , [Joan]183-joan . [I]0-i hate compliments and never pay them . [I]0-i told [you]183-joan , remember , that [your]183-joan wrists were a thought too big . " " [You]176-barron need n't be sayin ' it over an '[183-joan] over , [Mister Jan]241-mister jan , " [she]183-joan answered , [her]183-joan smile changing to a pout . " But [you]176-barron would n't like [me]0-i any more if [I]0-i stopped telling [you]183-joan the truth . [We]1311-we have agreed to love what is true and to worship [Mother Nature]178-nature because [she]178-nature always speaks the truth . " [The girl]521-the girl made no answer , and [he]176-barron went on working for a few moments , then spoke again . " [I]0-i 'm selfish , [Joan]183-joan , and think more of [my]176-barron picture than [I]176-barron do of [[my]176-barron little model]4008-my little model . Put down [your]183-joan arm and take a good rest . [I]176-barron tried holding [my]176-barron hand over [my]176-barron eyes yesterday to see how long [I]176-barron could do so without wearying [myself]176-barron . [I]176-barron found that three minutes was quite enough , but [I]176-barron have often kept [you]183-joan posed for five . " " It hurted [my]176-barron arm '[176-barron] tween the shoulder an ' elbow a lil bit at first , but [I]176-barron 've grawed used to it now . " " How ever shall [I]176-barron repay [you]183-joan , kind [Joan]183-joan , for all [your]183-joan trouble and [your]183-joan long walks and pretty stories ? " " [I]176-barron doan't need no pay . If '[176-barron] twas a matter o ' payin '[176-barron] , ' twould be a wrong thing to do , [I]176-barron reckon . [[Theer]4009-theer 's auld Bascombe up [Paul]267-paul — [him]267-paul wi '[176-barron] curls o ' long hair an '[176-barron] gawld rings in 's ears]267-paul . [Gents]268-gents pays en to take [his]268-gents likeness ; an ' [[theer]4009-theer 's [gals]3956-gals]4010-theer 's gals make money so , more'n wan ; but [faither]579-faither says '[268-gents] tis a heathenish way of livin ' an '[1313-i] not honest . An'—an ' [I]1313-i 'd never let [nobody]3503-nobody paint [me]1313-i else but [you]1313-i , [Mister Jan]241-mister jan , 'cause[1313-i] [you'm]1313-i different . " " Well , [you]1313-i make [me]0-i [a proud man]1314-a proud man , [Joan]183-joan . [I]0-i 'm afraid [I]1313-i must be a poor substitute for [Joe]192-joe . " [He]192-joe noticed [she]183-joan had never mentioned [[her]183-joan sweetheart]3626-her sweetheart since [their]4015-their early interviews , and wanted to ascertain of what nature was [Joan]183-joan 's affection for [the sailor]784-the sailor . [He]192-joe did not yet dream how faint a thing [poor Joe]192-joe had shrunk to be in [Joan]183-joan 's mind , or how the present episode in [her]183-joan life was dwarfing and dominating all others , present and past . Nor did [the girl]521-the girl 's answer to [his]192-joe remark enlighten [him]192-joe . " In coorse [you]1315-you an '[1313-i] [Joe]192-joe 's differ'nt as can be . [You]1315-you knaws everything seemin'ly an ' be [a gen'le - man]4018-a gen'le - man ; [Joe]192-joe 's only [a seafarin '[1315-you] man]4019-a seafarin ' man , an ' '[1316-e] [e]1316-e doan't knaw much ' cept what [he]192-joe 's larned from [faither]579-faither . But [Joe]192-joe used to say a sight more'n what [you]1315-you do , for all that . " " [I]1317-i like to hear [you]1315-you talk , [Joan]183-joan ; perhaps [Joe]192-joe liked to hear [himself]192-joe talk . [Most men]4021-most men do . But , [you]1315-you see , the things [you]1315-you have told [me]1317-i are pleasant to [me]1317-i and [they]4022-they were not to [Joe]192-joe , because [he]192-joe did n't believe in [them]4022-they . Do n't look at [me]1317-i , [Joan]183-joan ; look right away to [the edge of [the sea]463-the sea]3613-the edge of the sea . " " [You'm]1315-you surprised like as [I]1317-i talks to [ye]1315-you , [Mister Jan.]196-mister jan. Doan't [ladies]3909-ladies talk so free as what [I]1317-i do ? " " [Other women]4026-other women talk , but [they]4026-other women are very seldom in earnest like [you]1315-you are , [Joan]183-joan . [They]4026-other women do n't believe half [they]4026-other women say , [they]4026-other women pretend and make believe ; [they]4026-other women 've got to do so , poor things , because [the world]3624-the world [they]4026-other women live in is all built up on ancient foundations of great festering lies . The lies are carefully coated over and disinfected as much as possible and quite hidden out of sight , but [everybody]3758-everybody knows [they]4026-other women are there — [everybody]3758-everybody knows the quaking foundations [they]4026-other women tread upon . Civilization means universal civility , [I]1317-i suppose , [Joan]183-joan ; and to be civil to [everybody]3758-everybody argues a great power of telling lies . [People]749-people call it tact . But [I]1317-i do n't like [polite society]4032-polite society [myself]1317-i , because [my]1317-i nose is sensitive and [I]1317-i smell the stinking basis through all the pretty paint . [You]183-joan and [I]1317-i , [Joan]183-joan , belong to [Nature]178-nature . [She]178-nature is not always civil , but [you]183-joan can trust [her]178-nature ; [she]178-nature is seldom polite , but [she]178-nature never says what is not true . " " [You]1318-you talk as though '[1317-i] [e]1317-i ded'n much like [ladies an ' gen'lemen]4033-ladies an ' gen'lemen , same as [you]1318-you be . " " [I]4033-ladies an ' gen'lemen do n't , and [I]4033-ladies an ' gen'lemen 'm[4033-ladies an ' gen'lemen] not what [you]1318-you understand by ' [a gentleman]4034-a gentleman , '[183-joan] [Joan]183-joan . [Gentlemen]3908-gentlemen and [ladies]3909-ladies let [me]0-i go among [them]1321-them and mix with [them]1321-them , because [I]0-i happen to have a great deal of money — thousands and thousands of pounds . That opens the door to [[their]1321-them drawing - rooms]1322-their drawing - rooms , if [I]0-i wanted to open it , but [I]0-i do n't . [I]0-i 've seen [them]1321-them and gone about among [them]1321-them , and [I]0-i 'm sick of [them]1321-them . If [a man]467-a man wishes to know what [polite society]4032-polite society is let [him]467-a man go into it as [a very wealthy bachelor]4037-a very wealthy bachelor . [I]241-mister jan 'm[241-mister jan] not ' [a gentleman]4034-a gentleman , '[1323-i] [you]1323-i know , [Joan]183-joan , fortunately . " " Surely , [Mister Jan]241-mister jan ! " " No more than [you]1323-i 're [a lady]4039-a lady . But [I]1323-i can try to be gentle and manly , which is better . [You]183-joan and [I]1323-i come from the same class , [Joan]183-joan ; from [the people]4040-the people . The only difference is that [[my]1323-i father]4041-my father happened to make a huge fortune in [London]45-london . Guess what [he]4041-my father sold ? " " [I]1323-i dunnaw . " " Fish — just plaice and flounders and herrings and so forth . [He]4041-my father sold them by tens of thousands . [[Your]183-joan father]1068-your father sells them too . But what d'you think was the difference ? Why , [[your]183-joan father]1068-your father is [an honest man]4044-an honest man ; [mine]1323-i was n't . [The fishermen]558-the fishermen sold [their]558-the fishermen fish , after [they]558-the fishermen had had the trouble and danger of catching [them]558-the fishermen , to [[my]1323-i father]4041-my father ; and then [[my]1323-i father]4041-my father sold them again to [the public]4048-the public ; and [the fishermen]558-the fishermen got too little and [the public]4048-the public paid too much , and so — [I'm]1323-i [a very rich man]4051-a very rich man to - day — [the son of [a thief]4053-a thief]4052-the son of a thief . " " [Mister Jan]241-mister jan ! " " [Nobody]3503-nobody ever called [him]4053-a thief [a thief]4053-a thief but [me]1323-i . [He]4053-a thief was [a great star in [this same polite society]4057-this same polite society [I]1323-i speak of]4056-a great star in this same polite society i speak of . [He]4053-a thief fed [hundreds of fat people]4058-hundreds of fat people on the money that ought to have gone into [the fishermen]558-the fishermen 's pockets ; and [he]4053-a thief died after eating too much salmon and cucumber at [his]4053-a thief own table . Poetic justice , [you]241-mister jan know . There are stained glass windows up to [his]4053-a thief memory in [two churches]4060-two churches and tons of good white marble were wasted when [they]558-the fishermen made [his]4053-a thief grave . But [he]4053-a thief was [a thief]4053-a thief , just as surely as [[your]1324-you father]1068-your father is [an honest man]4044-an honest man ; so [you]1324-you have the advantage of [me]1323-i , [Joan]183-joan . [I]1323-i really doubt if [I]1323-i 'm[1323-i] respectable enough for [you]1324-you to know and trust . " " [I]0-i 'd trust ' [e]1324-you with anything , [Mister Jan]241-mister jan , 'cause[0-i] [you'm]0-i plain - spoken an ' true . " " Do n't be too sure — [the son of]4064-the son of [a thief]4053-a thief may have wrong ideas and lax principles . Many things not to be bought can easily be stolen . " Again [he]1323-i struck a sinister note , but this time on an ear wholly unable to appreciate or suspect it . [Joan]183-joan was occupied with [Barron]176-barron 's startling scraps of biography , and , as usual , when [he]176-barron began talking in a way [she]183-joan could not understand , turned to [her]183-joan own thoughts . This sudden alteration of [his]176-barron position [she]183-joan took literally . It struck [her]183-joan in a happy light . " If [you'm]176-barron not [a gen'leman]4066-a gen'leman then [you]176-barron wouldn '[0-i] look down ' pon [me]0-i , would '[0-i] [e]1325-e ? " " God forbid ! [I]0-i look up to [you]0-i , [Joan]183-joan . " [She]183-joan was silent , trying to master this remarkable assertion . [The artist]3491-the artist stood no longer upon that lofty pedestal where [she]183-joan had placed [him]3491-the artist ; but the change of attitude seemed to bring [him]3491-the artist a little closer , and [Joan]183-joan forgot the fall in contemplating the nearer approach . " That 's why [I]0-i asked [you]183-joan not to call [me]0-i ' [Mister Jan]241-mister jan , " '[176-barron] [Barron]176-barron added after a pause . " [We]1327-we are , [you]183-joan see , only different because [I]0-i 'm [a man]467-a man and [you]183-joan 're[176-barron] [a woman]3541-a woman . Money merely makes a difference to outside things , like [houses]1329-houses and clothes . But [you]183-joan 've got possessions which no money can bring to [me]0-i : [a happy home]1330-a happy home and [a lover coming back to [you]183-joan from [the sea]463-the sea]1331-a lover coming back to you from the sea . Think what it must be to have [[nobody]3503-nobody in [the world]3624-the world]1334-nobody in the world to care whether [you]183-joan live or die . Why , [I]0-i have n't a relation near enough to be even interested in all [my]0-i money — there 's loneliness for [you]183-joan ! " [Joan]183-joan felt full of a great pity , but could not tell how to express it . Even [her]183-joan dull brains were not slow enough to credit [his]0-i frank assertion that [he]0-i and [she]183-joan were [equals]1336-equals ; but [she]183-joan accepted the statement in some degree , and now , with [her]183-joan mind wandering in [his]0-i lonely existence , wondered if [she]183-joan might presume to express sympathy for [him]0-i and proclaim [herself]183-joan [[his]0-i friend]494-his friend . [She]183-joan hesitated , for such friendship as [hers]183-joan , though it came hot from [her]183-joan little heart , seemed a ludicrous thing to offer [this man]3526-this man . Every day of intercourse with [him]0-i filled [her]183-joan more with wonder and with admiration ; every day [he]0-i occupied a wider place in [her]183-joan thoughts ; and at that moment [his]0-i utterances and [his]0-i declaration of a want in life made [him]0-i more human than ever to [her]183-joan , more easily to be comprehended , more within the reach of [her]183-joan understanding . And that was not a circumstance calculated to lessen [her]183-joan regard for [him]0-i by any means . Until that day [he]0-i had appeared a being far apart , whose interests and main threads of life belonged to another sphere ; now [he]0-i had deliberately come into [[her]183-joan world]1339-her world and declared it [his]0-i own . The silence became painful to [Joan]183-joan , but [she]183-joan could not pluck up courage enough to tell [the artist]3491-the artist that [she]183-joan at least was [a friend]691-a friend . Finally [she]183-joan spoke , feeling that [he]0-i waited for [her]183-joan to do so , and [her]183-joan words led to the point , for [she]183-joan found , in [his]0-i answer to them , that [he]0-i took [her]183-joan goodwill for granted . " Ai n't [you]0-i got [no uncles]1342-no uncles nor nothin' o ' that even , [Mister Jan]241-mister jan ? " [He]0-i laughed and shook [his]0-i head . " Not one , [Joan]183-joan — [not anybody in [all the world]3556-all the world]4068-not anybody in all the world to think twice about [me]0-i but [you]183-joan . " [Her]183-joan heart beat hard and [her]183-joan breath quickened , but [she]183-joan did not speak . Then [Barron]176-barron , putting down [his]0-i brushes and beginning to load a pipe , that [his]0-i next remark might not seem too serious , proceeded : " [I]0-i call [you]183-joan '[0-i] [friend]1343-friend , ' [Joan]183-joan , because [I]1344-he know [you]183-joan are [one]3502-one . And [I]1344-he want [you]183-joan to think of [me]1344-he sometimes when [I]1344-he am gone , will [you]183-joan ? " [He]0-i went on filling [his]0-i pipe , and then , looking suddenly into [her]183-joan eyes , saw there a light that was strange — a light that [he]0-i would have given [his]0-i soul to put into paint — a light that [Joe]192-joe 's name never had kindled and never could . [Joan]183-joan wiped [her]183-joan hand across [her]183-joan mouth uneasily ; then [she]183-joan twisted [her]183-joan hands behind [her]183-joan back , like [a schoolgirl standing in class]4071-a schoolgirl standing in class , and made answer with [her]183-joan eyes on the ground . " [Iss]194-iss , [I]1344-he will , then , [Mister Jan]241-mister jan ; an '[1344-he] maybe [I]0-i could n't help it if [I]0-i would . " [He]1344-he lighted [his]1344-he pipe carefully before answering . " Then [I]0-i shall be happy , [Joan]183-joan . " But while [she]183-joan grew rose - red at the boldness of [her]183-joan sudden announcement , [he]1344-he took care neither to look at [her]183-joan nor to let [her]183-joan know that [he]1344-he had realized the earnestness with which [she]183-joan spoke . And when , ten minutes later , [she]183-joan had departed , [he]1344-he mused speculatively on the course of [their]1345-their conversation , asking [himself]1344-he what whim had led [him]1344-he to pretend to so much human feeling and to lament [his]1344-he loneliness . This condition of [his]1344-he life [he]1344-he loved above all others . [No man]3523-no man , [woman]1347-woman or [child]1348-child had the right to interfere with [his]1344-he selfish , impersonal existence , and [he]1344-he gloried in the fact . But to the scraps of [his]1344-he life 's history , which [he]1344-he had spread before [Joan]183-joan in [their]1345-their absolute truth , [he]1344-he had added this fiction of friendless loneliness , and it had worked a wonder . [He]1344-he saw that [he]1344-he was growing to be much to [her]183-joan , and the problem lying in [his]1344-he path rose again , as it had for a moment when [Murdoch]175-murdoch warned [him]1344-he in jest against falling in love with [Joan Tregenza]183-joan . Dim suspicions crossed [his]1344-he mind with greater frequency , and being now [a mere remorseless savage]1349-a mere remorseless savage , hunting to its completion a fine picture , [he]1344-he made no effort to shut their shadows from [his]1344-he calculation . Everything which bore even indirectly upon [his]1344-he work received its share of attention ; to mood must all sacrifices be made ; and now a new mood began to dawn in [him]1344-he . [He]1344-he knew it , [he]1344-he accepted it . [He]1344-he had not sought it , but the thing was there , and [Nature]178-nature had sent it to [him]1344-he . To shun it and fly from it meant a lie to [his]1344-he art ; to open [his]1344-he arms to it promised the destruction of [a human unit]1350-a human unit . [Barron]176-barron was not [the man to hesitate between two such courses]1351-the man to hesitate between two such courses . If any action could heighten [his]1344-he inspiration , add a glimmer of glory to [his]1344-he picture , or get a shadow more soul into the painted blue eyes of [the subject]1352-the subject , [he]1344-he held such action justified . For the present [his]1344-he mind was chaos on the subject , and [he]1344-he left the future to work itself out as chance might determine . [His]1344-he painting was all [he]1344-he concerned [himself]1344-he with , and should [Nature]178-nature ultimately indicate that greater perfection might be achieved through worship and even sacrifice at [[her]178-nature shrine]3543-her shrine , neither worship nor sacrifice would be withheld . [Joan Tregenza]183-joan went [home]453-home in a dream that day . [She]183-joan did not know where to begin thinking . " [Mister Jan]241-mister jan " had told [her]183-joan so many astounding things ; and [her]183-joan own heart , too , had made bold utterances — concerning matters which [she]183-joan had crushed out of sight with some shame and many secret blushes until now . But , seen in the light of [John Barron]176-barron 's revelations , this emotion which [she]183-joan had thrust so resolutely to the back of [her]183-joan mind could remain there no more . It arose strong , rampant and ridiculous ; only from [her]183-joan point of view no humor distinguished it . [This man]3526-this man , then , was like [herself]183-joan , made of the same flesh and blood , sprung from [the people]4040-the people . That fact , though possessing absolutely no significance whatever in reality , struck [Joan]183-joan with great force . [Her]183-joan highly primitive instincts stretched a wide gulf between the thing called " [gentleman "]1357-gentleman " and [other men]1358-other men ; which was the result of training from [parents of the old - fashioned sort , whose world lay outside and behind the modern spirit]1359-parents of the old - fashioned sort , whose world lay outside and behind the modern spirit ; who had reached the highest development of [their]1359-parents of the old - fashioned sort , whose world lay outside and behind the modern spirit intelligence and formed [their]1359-parents of the old - fashioned sort , whose world lay outside and behind the modern spirit opinions before the passing of the Education Act . [Gray Michael]204-gray michael naturally held the great ones of [the earth]3591-the earth as objects of pity from an eternal standpoint , but birth weighed with [him]204-gray michael , and , in temporal concerns , [he]204-gray michael treated [[his]204-gray michael superiors]1361-his superiors with all respect and civility when rare chance brought [him]204-gray michael into contact with [them]1361-his superiors . [He]204-gray michael viewed uneasily the last outcome of progress and the vastly increased facilities for instruction of [the juvenile population]1362-the juvenile population . The age was sufficiently godless , in [his]204-gray michael judgment ; and [he]204-gray michael had found that [a Board School]1363-a board school education was the first nail in the coffin of [every young man]1364-every young man 's faith . [Joan]183-joan , therefore , allowing nothing for the value of riches , of education , of intellect , was content to accept [Barron]176-barron 's own cynical statement in a spirit widely different from [the speaker]1365-the speaker 's . [He]176-barron had sneered at [himself]176-barron , just as [he]176-barron had sneered at [[his]176-barron own dead father]1366-his own dead father . But [Joan]183-joan missed all the bitterness of [his]176-barron speech . To [her]183-joan [he]176-barron was simply [a wondrously honest man who loved truth for itself , who could never utter anything not true , who held it no offense to speak truth even of the dead]1367-a wondrously honest man who loved truth for itself , who could never utter anything not true , who held it no offense to speak truth even of the dead . Gentle or simple , [he]176-barron seemed infinitely superior to [all men whom [she]183-joan had met with]1368-all men whom she had met with . And yet this beautiful nature walked through [the world]3624-the world quite alone . [He]176-barron had asked [her]183-joan to remember [him]176-barron when [he]176-barron was gone ; [he]176-barron had said that [she]183-joan was [[his]176-barron friend]494-his friend . And [he]176-barron cared little for [women]1371-women — there was perhaps [no other woman in [the world]3624-the world [he]176-barron had called [a friend]691-a friend]1372-no other woman in the world he had called a friend . Then [the girl]521-the girl 's heart fluttered at the presumption of [her]521-the girl silly , soaring thoughts , and [she]521-the girl glanced nervously to the right and to the left of [the lonely road]1376-the lonely road , as though fearful that [some hidden eavesdropper]1377-some hidden eavesdropper might peep into [her]521-the girl open mind . The magic spell was upon [her]521-the girl . [This little , pale , clever man , so quiet , so strange , so unlike anything else within [her]521-the girl seventeen years of experience]1378-this little , pale , clever man , so quiet , so strange , so unlike anything else within her seventeen years of experience , had wrought Nature 's vital miracle , and [Joan]183-joan , who , until then , believed [herself]183-joan in love with [[her]183-joan sailor sweetheart]1379-her sailor sweetheart , now stood aghast before the truth , stood bewildered between the tame and bloodless fantasy of [her]183-joan affection for [Joe Noy]192-joe and this wild , live reality . [She]183-joan looked far back into a past already dim and remembered that [she]183-joan had told [Joe]192-joe many times how [she]183-joan loved [him]192-joe with all [her]183-joan heart . But the words were spoken before [she]183-joan knew that [she]183-joan possessed a heart at all . Yet [Joe]192-joe then formed [no inconsiderable figure in life]1380-no inconsiderable figure in life . [She]183-joan had looked forward to marriage with [him]192-joe as a comfortable and sufficient background for present existence ; [she]183-joan had viewed [Joe]192-joe as [a handsome , solid figure]1381-a handsome , solid figure — [a man well thought of , one who would give [her]183-joan a home with [bigger rooms]1383-bigger rooms and better furniture in [it]1384-it than [[most fishermen]1385-most fishermen 's daughters]1386-most fishermen 's daughters might reasonably hope for]1382-a man well thought of , one who would give her a home with bigger rooms and better furniture in it than most fishermen 's daughters might reasonably hope for . But this new blinding light was more than the memory of [Joe]192-joe could face uninjured . [He]192-joe shriveled and shrank in it . Like [[St. Michael]191-michael 's Mount]4-st. michael 's mount , seen afar , through curtains of rain , [Joe]192-joe had once bulked large , towering , even grand , but under noonday sun the great mass dwindles as a whole though every detail becomes more apparent ; and so with poor [Joe Noy]192-joe . Removed to a distance of a thousand miles though [he]192-joe was , [Joan]183-joan had never known [him]192-joe better , never realized the height , breadth , depth of [him]192-joe so acutely as now [she]183-joan did . The former ignorance in such a case had been bliss indeed , for whereunto [her]183-joan present acquired wisdom might point even [she]183-joan dared not consider . [Any other girl]1387-any other girl must have remained sufficiently alive to the enormous disparity every way between [herself]183-joan and [the artist]3491-the artist ; and [Joan]183-joan grasped the difference , but from the wrong point of view . [The man]3494-the man 's delicacy of discernment , [his]3494-the man wisdom , [his]3494-the man love of the things which [she]183-joan loved , [his]3494-the man fine feeling , [his]3494-the man humility — all combined in [Joan]183-joan 's judgment to place [him]3494-the man far above [herself]183-joan , though [she]183-joan had not words to name the qualities ; but whereas [another lowly woman]1390-another lowly woman , reaching this point , must , if [she]1390-another lowly woman possessed any mother - wit or knowledge of [the world]3624-the world , have awakened to the danger and grown guarded , [Joan]183-joan , claiming little wit to speak of , and being an empty vessel so far as knowledge of [the world]3624-the world was concerned , saw no danger and allowed [her]183-joan thoughts to run away with [her]183-joan in a wholly insane direction . This [she]183-joan did for two reasons : because [she]183-joan felt absolutely safe , and because [she]183-joan suspected that [Nature]178-nature , who was " [[Mister Jan]241-mister jan 's " God]1393-mister jan 's " god , had now come to be [[her]183-joan God]1394-her god also . [The man]3494-the man was very wise , and [he]3494-the man hated everything which lacked truth : therefore [he]3494-the man would always do what was right , and [he]3494-the man would not be less true to [her]183-joan than [he]3494-the man was to [the world]3624-the world . [Truth]269-truth was [his]3494-the man guiding star , and [he]3494-the man had always found [Nature]178-nature true . Therefore , why should not [Joan]183-joan find it true ? [Nature]178-nature was talking to [her]183-joan now and teaching [her]183-joan rapidly . [She]183-joan must be content to wait and learn . [The two men]1397-the two men , [Noy]192-joe and [Barren]177-barren , fairly represented the opposite views of life each entertained , and [Joan]183-joan felt the new music wake a thousand sleeping echoes in [her]183-joan heart while the old grew more harsh and unlovely as [she]183-joan considered it . [Joe]192-joe had so many opinions and so little information ; " [Mister Jan]241-mister jan " knew everything and asserted nothing save what [Nature]178-nature had taught [him]241-mister jan . [Joe]192-joe was so self - righteous and overbearing , so like [[her]183-joan father]3642-her father , so convinced that [Luke Gospeldom]242-luke gospeldom was the only gate to glory ; " [Mister Jan]241-mister jan " had said there was more of the Everlasting [God]179-god in a bluebell than in the whole of the Old Testament ; [he]241-mister jan had declared that the smell of the gorse and the sunshine on [the deep sea]1399-the deep sea were better things than the incense and banners at [St. Peter 's]39-st. peter ; [he]241-mister jan had asserted that the purring of kittens was sweeter to [the Father of all]1400-the father of all than the thunder of a mighty organ played in [the noblest cathedral]1401-the noblest cathedral ever made with hands . All these foolish and inconsequent comparisons , uttered thoughtlessly by [Barron]176-barron 's lips while [his]176-barron mind was on [his]176-barron picture , seemed very fine to [Joan]183-joan ; and the finer because [she]183-joan did not understand them . Again , [Joe]192-joe rarely listened to [her]183-joan ; [this man]3526-this man always did , and [he]3526-this man liked to hear [her]183-joan talk : [he]3526-this man had declared as much . [Her]183-joan brains almost hurt [Joan]183-joan on [her]183-joan way back to [the white cottage]841-the white cottage that morning . [They]1404-they seemed so loaded ; they lifted [her]183-joan up high above the working - day world and made [her]183-joan feel many years older . Such reflections and ideas came to [grown women]1405-grown women doubtless , [she]183-joan thought . A great unrest arose from the shadows of these varied speculations — a great unrest and disquiet — a feeling of coming change , like the note in the air when the swallows meet together in autumn , like the whisper of the leaves on the high tops of [the forest]1406-the forest before rain . [Her]183-joan heart was very full . [She]183-joan walked more slowly as the thoughts weighed heavier ; [she]183-joan went back to [[her]183-joan home]1297-her home round - eyed and solemn , wondering at many things , at the extension of the horizon of life , at the mental picture of [Joe]192-joe standing clearly out of the mists , viewed from [a woman]3541-a woman 's standpoint . That day much serving awaited [her]183-joan ; but , at every turn and pause in the small affairs of [her]183-joan duty , [Joan]183-joan 's mind swooped back like a hawk to the easel on [Gorse Point]42-gorse point ; and when it did , [her]183-joan cheeks flushed and [she]183-joan turned to bend over sink or pig 's trough to hide the new fire that burned in [her]183-joan heart and lighted [her]183-joan eyes . [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza , who had suffered from neuralgia and profound depression of spirit upon [Tom]199-tom 's departure to [the sea]463-the sea , but who comforted [herself]198-mrs. tregenza even in [her]198-mrs. tregenza darkest hour by reflection that [no lugger boy]1410-no lugger boy ever joined the fishing fleet with such an equipment of new clothes as [[her]198-mrs. tregenza son]836-her son , was somewhat better and more cheerful now that [the lad]761-the lad had made [his]761-the lad first trip and survived it . Moreover , [Tom]199-tom would be [home]453-home again that night in all probability , and , since [Michael]191-michael was last [ashore]1414-ashore , [the butcher from [Paul]182-tarrant]1415-the butcher from paul had called and offered three shillings and sixpence more for the next pig to be killed than ever [a Tregenza pig had fetched until that day]1416-a tregenza pig had fetched until that day . Life therefore held some prosperity in it , even for [Thomasin]201-thomasin . After [their]1417-they dinner both women , [the elder with a shawl muffled about [her]1418-the elder with a shawl muffled about her face face]1418-the elder with a shawl muffled about her face , went down [the road]445-the road to [Newlyn]1-newlyn to see a sight . [They]1417-they stopped at [[George Trevennick]270-george trevennick 's little house]1420-george trevennick 's little house . [It]1420-george trevennick 's little house had [a garden]1421-a garden in front of [it]1420-george trevennick 's little house with a short flagstaff erected thereon , and all looked neat , trim and ship - shape as became [the home of [a retired Royal Navy man]1423-a retired royal navy man]1422-the home of a retired royal navy man . A wedding was afoot , and [Mr. Trevennick]271-mr. trevennick , who never lost an opportunity to display [his]271-mr. trevennick rare store of bunting , had plentifully shaken out bright reds and yellows , blues and greens . The little flags fluttered in four streamers from the head of the flagstaff , and [their]1424-their colors looked harsh and crude until associated with the human interests [they]1424-their marked . Already many [children]1425-children gazed with awe from [the road]445-the road , while [a favored few]1427-a favored few , including [the Tregenzas]218-the tregenzas , stood in [[Mr. Trevennick]271-mr. trevennick 's garden]1428-mr. trevennick 's garden , which was raised above [the causeway]1429-the causeway . Great good - humor prevailed , together with some questionable jesting , and [Joan]183-joan heard the merriment with a sense of discomfort . [They]1417-they would talk like this when [Joe]192-joe came back to marry [her]183-joan ; but the great day of [a maid]1430-a maid 's life had lost its greatness for [her]183-joan now . The rough , good - natured fun grated on [her]183-joan nerves as it had never grated before ; because , though [she]183-joan only guessed at the sly jokes of [[her]183-joan elders]1431-her elders , something told [her]183-joan that " [Mister Jan]241-mister jan " would have found no pleasure in such merriment . [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza talked , [Mr. Trevennick]271-mr. trevennick smoked , and [Sally Trevennick]272-sally , [[the old sailor]1432-the old sailor 's daughter]1433-the old sailor 's daughter , entertained [the party]1434-the party and had a word for all . [She]272-sally was not young , and not well - favored , and unduly plump , but [a sweet - hearted woman]1435-a sweet - hearted woman nevertheless , with a great love for [the little children]1436-the little children . This indeed presently appeared , for while [the party]1434-the party waited there happened a tragedy in [the street]1438-the street which brought extreme sorrow to [a pair of very small people]1439-a pair of very small people . [They]1439-a pair of very small people had a big crabshell full of dirt off [the road]445-the road which [they]1439-a pair of very small people drew after [them]1439-a pair of very small people by a string , and in which [they]1439-a pair of very small people took no small pride and pleasure ; but [a young sailor]1441-a young sailor , coming hastily round a corner , trampled upon the shell , smashed it , and passed laughing on . [The infants]1442-the infants , overwhelmed by this sudden disaster to [their]1442-the infants most cherished earthly possession , crushed to the earth by this blotting out of the sunshine of the day , lifted up [their]1442-the infants voices and wept before the shattered ruins . [One]3502-one , the biggest , dropped the useless string and put [his]3502-one face against the wall , that [his]3502-one extreme grief might be hidden ; but [the smaller]1444-the smaller hesitated not to make [his]3502-one sorrows widely known . [He]3502-one bawled , then took a deep breath and bawled again . As the full extent of [his]3502-one loss was borne in upon [him]3502-one , [he]3502-one absolutely danced with access of frenzied grief ; and [everybody]3758-everybody laughed but fat [Sally Trevennick]272-sally . [Her]272-sally black eyes grew clouded , and [she]272-sally went down into [the road]445-the road to bring comfort to [the sufferers]1447-the sufferers . " Never mind , then ; never mind , [[you]1448-you bwoys]1449-you bwoys ; us'll get ' [e]4072-e [another braave shell]4073-another braave shell , so [us]4074-us will . " [She]272-sally took a hand of [each babe]1450-each babe and brought [them]1450-each babe into [the garden]3656-the garden , from which [they]1450-each babe could look down upon [[their]1450-each babe fellows]1452-their fellows . Such exaltation naturally soothed [their]1450-each babe sufferings , and amid many gasps and gurgles [they]1450-each babe found a return to peace in the close contemplation of [Mr. Trevennick]271-mr. trevennick 's flagstaff and the discussion of a big saffron pasty . Presently [the bridegroom]1453-the bridegroom and [[his]1453-the bridegroom young brother]1454-his young brother passed on the way to [church]581-church . [Both]3485-both looked the reverse of happy ; [both]3485-both wore [their]3485-both Sunday broadcloth , and both swung along as fast as [their]3485-both legs would carry [them]3485-both . [They]3485-both were red hot and going five miles an hour ; but , though [Mousehole men]1458-mousehole men , [everybody in Newlyn]1459-everybody in newlyn knew [them]3485-both , and [they]3485-both were forced to run the gauntlet of much chaff . " [The little bride]4089-the little bride advanced between [[her]4089-the little bride father]3642-her father and [mother]756-mother , while [relations]4092-relations and [friends]1078-friends marched two and two behind . [Mr. Penn]274-mr. penn looked up at the flags as [he]274-mr. penn limped along , and a great delight broke out upon [his]274-mr. penn face ; [[the bride]4098-the bride 's mother]4099-the bride 's mother beamed with satisfaction at a compliment not by any means expected , for [the Penns]275-the penns were [a humble folk]4100-a humble folk ; and [the bride]4098-the bride blushed and stole a nervous peep at the display . But [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza only shook [her]198-mrs. tregenza head and sighed . " [You]1479-you speaks as [a onmarried wummon]1480-a onmarried wummon , [Sarah]272-sally ; but if [you]1479-you comed to be [a bride]1481-a bride [you]1479-you 'd sing dif - fer'nt . No honeymoon 's wrong , an ' [your]1479-you faither'll tell the same . " [Mr. Trevennick]271-mr. trevennick admitted that no honeymoon was bad . [He]271-mr. trevennick went further and declared the omission of such an institution to be unprincipled . [He]271-mr. trevennick even said that had [he]271-mr. trevennick known of this serious defect in the ceremonies [he]271-mr. trevennick should certainly have abstained from lending the brightness of [his]271-mr. trevennick bunting to [them]4115-them . Then [he]271-mr. trevennick went to eye the flags from different points of view , while [Sally]272-sally , in a minority of one , turned to [Joan]183-joan . " And what do [you]1479-you say ? " [she]198-mrs. tregenza asked . " [You'm]1479-you '[198-mrs. tregenza] mazin ' quiet an '[198-mrs. tregenza] tongue - tied for [you]1479-you . [I]0-i s'pose [you'm]1479-you thinkin ' of the time when [Joe Noy]192-joe comes [home]453-home . [I]198-mrs. tregenza lay [you]1479-you 'll have a honeymoon anyways . " " Iss , that [you]1479-you may depend '[198-mrs. tregenza] pon , " said [Mrs. Tregenza]198-mrs. tregenza . And [Joan]183-joan , who had in truth been thinking of [[her]183-joan sweetheart]3626-her sweetheart 's return , grew red , whereat [they]1483-they all laughed . But [she]183-joan felt secretly superior to [every one of [them]1483-they]1484-every one of them , for the shrinking process began to extend beyond [Joe]192-joe now . A fortnight before , [she]183-joan had been much gratified by allusions to the future and felt [herself]183-joan [an important individual enough]1485-an important individual enough . Then , [she]183-joan must have shared [[her]183-joan stepmother]760-her stepmother 's pity at the poverty of the pageant which had just passed by . But now [the world]3624-the world had changed . Matrimony with [Joe Noy]192-joe was not a subject which brought present delight to [her]183-joan , but [the little bride who had just gone to [her]183-joan wedding]1488-the little bride who had just gone to her wedding filled [Joan]183-joan 's thoughts . What was in [that girl]1489-that girl 's heart , [she]183-joan greatly wondered . Did [Milly Penn]278-milly penn feel for long - legged [Mark Taskes]273-mark taskes what [Joan]183-joan felt for " [Mister Jan]241-mister jan " ? Was it possible that [any other woman]1490-any other woman had ever experienced similar mysterious splendors of mind ? [She]183-joan could not tell , but it seemed unlikely to [her]183-joan ; it appeared improbable that [an ordinary man]1491-an ordinary man had power to inspire another heart with such golden magic as glorified [her]183-joan own . Presently [she]183-joan departed with [[her]183-joan stepmother]760-her stepmother , whereupon [Sally Trevennick]272-sally relieved [her]183-joan pent - up feelings . " Thank the Lard that chitter - faaced wummon edn ' gwaine to the weddin '[272-sally] any ways ! [Us]1493-us knaws [she]1489-that girl 's [a dear good sawl ' nough]4117-a dear good sawl ' nough ; but what wi '[1489-that girl] [her]1489-that girl sour voice , an ' [her]1489-that girl sour way o '[1489-that girl] talkin ' , an '[1489-that girl] [her]1489-that girl sour ' pinions , she'm enough to set a rat - trap 's teeth on edge . " That evening [Thomasin]201-thomasin had another spasm of face - ache and went to bed soon after drinking tea . [Michael]191-michael was due at [home]453-home about ten o'clock or earlier , and [Joan]183-joan — having set out supper , made all ready , and ascertained that [[her]183-joan stepmother]760-her stepmother had gone to sleep — walked out to [the pierhead]4120-the pierhead , there to wait for [Mr. Tregenza]216-mr. tregenza and [Tom]199-tom . Under moonlight , [the returning luggers]4121-the returning luggers crept homeward , like inky silhouettes on a background of dull silver . Every moment added to the forest of masts anchored at [the moorings outside [the harbor]458-the harbor]4122-the moorings outside the harbor ; every minute [another rowing - boat]4124-another rowing - boat shot between the granite piers , slid silently into the darkness under [shore]557-shore , leaving moonlit rings widening out behind at each dip of the oars . [Joan]183-joan sat down under [the lighthouse]886-the lighthouse and waited in the stillness for [[her]183-joan father]3642-her father 's boat . Yellow flashes , like fireflies , twinkled along through [Newlyn]1-newlyn , and above them the moon brought out square patches of silver - bright roof seen through a blue night . Now and then a bell rang in [the harbor]458-the harbor , and lights leaped here and there , mingling red snakes and streamers of fire with the white moonbeams where they lay on still water . Then [Joan]183-joan knew the fish were being sold by auction , and [she]183-joan grew anxious for [[her]183-joan father]3642-her father 's return , fearing prices might have fallen before [he]3642-her father arrived . Great periods of silence lay between the ringings of the bell , and at such times only faint laughter floated out from [shore]557-shore , or blocks chipped and rattled as a sail came down or a concertina squeaked fitfully where it was played on [a Norwegian iceboat]4131-a norwegian iceboat at [the harbor quay]4132-the harbor quay . The tide ran high , and [Joan]183-joan watched the lights reflected in [the harbor]458-the harbor and wondered why the gold of them contrasted so ill with the silver from the moon . Presently [two men]482-two men came along to [the pierhead]4120-the pierhead . [They]482-two men smoked , looked at [the sea]463-the sea , and did not notice [her]183-joan where [she]183-joan sat in shadow . One , [the larger]4137-the larger , wore knickerbockers , talked loudly , and looked [a giant in the vague light]4138-a giant in the vague light ; the other was muffled up in a big ulster , and [Joan]183-joan would not have recognized [Barron]176-barron had [he]176-barron not spoken . But [he]176-barron answered [[his]176-barron friend]494-his friend , and then [the girl]521-the girl 's heart leaped to hear that quiet , unimpassioned voice . [He]176-barron spoke of matters which [she]183-joan did not understand , of pictures and light and all manner of puzzles set by Nature for the solution of art ; but though for the most part [his]176-barron remarks conveyed no meaning to [her]183-joan , yet [he]176-barron closed a sentence with words that made [her]183-joan happy , and warmed [her]183-joan heart and left a precious memory behind [them]482-two men . " Moonlight is a problem only less difficult than sunshine , " [he]176-barron said to [[his]176-barron friend]494-his friend . " Where are [you]494-his friend going to get that ? " and [he]176-barron pointed to [the sea]463-the sea . " It 's been jolly well done all the same . " " Never . It is not to be done . [You]494-his friend can suggest by a trick , but [God]179-god defend [us]4143-us from tricks and sleight - of - hand in connection with the solemn business of painting pictures . Let [us]4143-us be true or nothing . " [They]4143-us walked away together , and [Joan]183-joan pondered over the last words . Truth seemed an eternal , abiding passion with [John Barron]176-barron , and the contemplation of this idea gave [her]183-joan considerable pleasure . [She]183-joan did not know that [a man]467-a man may be at once true to [his]467-a man art and [a liar to [[his]467-a man fellows]4146-his fellows]4145-a liar to his fellows . Presently [[her]183-joan father]3642-her father returned with [Tom]199-tom , and [the three]4148-the three walked [home]453-home together . [Gray Michael]204-gray michael appeared quietly satisfied that [[his]204-gray michael son]869-his son was shaping well and showing courage and nerve . But [he]204-gray michael silenced [the lad]761-the lad quickly enough when [Tom]199-tom began to talk with some gasconade concerning greet deeds done westward of [the Scilly Islands]40-the scilly islands . " It ban't the wave as makes most splash what gaws highest up [the beach]1496-the beach , mind . [You]1495-you get [Joan]183-joan to teach ' [e]1495-you how to peel '[216-mr. tregenza] taties , 'cause '[216-mr. tregenza] tis a job [you]1495-you made a tidy bawk of , not to mention no other . An ' mind — the bwoat 's clean as a smelt by five o'clock to - morrow marnin '[216-mr. tregenza] , an ' no later . " [Tom]199-tom , dashed by these base details , answered [seaman]279-seaman fashion : " Ay , ay , [faither]579-faither . " Then [they]4153-they all tramped [home]453-home , and [the boy]3680-the boy enjoyed the glories of a late supper , though [he]3680-the boy was half asleep before [he]3680-the boy had finished it . By half - past five o'clock , [Mr. Tregenza]216-mr. tregenza 's black lugger was off again in a gray dawn all tangled with gold on the eastern horizon . [[His]3680-the boy mother]752-his mother had given [Tom]199-tom an early breakfast at half - past four , and [the youngster]4157-the youngster , agape and dim - eyed at first , speedily brightened up , for [he]4157-the youngster had [a willing listener]1082-a willing listener , in the candle - light and poured a tale of moving incidents into [Thomasin]201-thomasin 's proud but uneasy mind . [She]183-joan determined therefore to reach [Gorse Point]42-gorse point before [the artist]3491-the artist should arrive there , and set off accordingly . Early though [she]183-joan was , [she]183-joan had but a short time to wait , for [Barron]176-barron appeared with [his]176-barron big canvas by nine o'clock . " " [Me]0-i , [Mister Jan]241-mister jan ! [You]0-i must a bin dreamin ' ! " " Yes , of course [I]1512-i was ; but such a lovely dream , [Joan]183-joan ! [You]183-joan see , [men who paint pictures and love what is beautiful and dream about beautiful things]4172-men who paint pictures and love what is beautiful and dream about beautiful things and [beautiful people]4173-beautiful people see all sorts of visions sometimes . [I]1512-i have pictures in [my]1512-i head a thousand times more splendid than any [I]1512-i shall ever put upon canvas , because mere paint - brushes can not do much , even when they are in the cleverest hands ; but [a man]467-a man 's brain is not bound down by material , mechanical matters . [My]1512-i brain made a picture of [you]183-joan last night — a picture that came and looked at [me]1512-i on [my]1512-i fern bed — a picture so real , so alive that [I]1512-i could see it move and hear it laugh . [You]183-joan think that wonderful . It is n't really , because [my]1512-i brain has done nothing but think of [you]183-joan now for nearly six weeks . [My]1512-i eye studies [you]183-joan and stamps [you]183-joan upon [my]1512-i brain ; then , when night comes , and [no man]3523-no man works , and [the world]3624-the world is dark and silent , [my]1512-i brain sets off on its own account and raises up a magic vision just to show [me]1512-i what [you]183-joan really are — how different to this poor daub here . But [I]0-i did n't . " " An ' what did this here misty sort o '[3848-maid] [maid]3848-maid say to ' [e]4177-e ? " " Strange things , strange things . Things [I]3848-maid would give a great deal to hear [you]1514-you say . " " Why , [you]1514-you said that [you]1514-you were not going to leave [me]3848-maid any more ; that [you]1514-you believed in [me]3848-maid and that [you]1514-you had come to [me]3848-maid because it was bad for [a man]467-a man to live all alone in [the world]3624-the world . " Thereupon [the girl]521-the girl asked a question which seemed to argue some sharpening of intelligence within [her]521-the girl . " [I]0-i should n't have told [you]183-joan that , [Joan]183-joan , only [you]183-joan asked [me]0-i . [You]183-joan see , in dreams , [we]1517-us are real in some senses , though unreal in others . In dreams [the savage part of [us]1517-us]1518-the savage part of us comes to the top and [Nature]178-nature can whisper to [us]1517-us . [She]178-nature chooses night to do so and often speaks to [men in visions]1519-men in visions , because by day the voice of [the world]3624-the world is in [their]1519-men in visions ears and [they]1519-men in visions have no attention for any other . It was strange , too , that [I]0-i should fancy such a thing — should imagine [I]0-i was kissing [you]183-joan — because [I]0-i never kissed [a woman]3541-a woman in [my]0-i life . " [Joan]183-joan took a long breath before this tremendous assertion . [He]0-i had told [her]183-joan in so many words that [he]0-i was fond of [her]183-joan ; and [he]0-i had mentioned it most casually as a point long since decided . Here was the question which [she]183-joan had asked [herself]183-joan so often answered once for all . [Her]183-joan heart leaped at tidings of great joy , and as [she]183-joan looked up into [his]0-i face [the man]3494-the man saw infinite wonder and delight in [her]183-joan own . [Mind]282-mind was adding beauty to flesh , and [he]0-i , fast losing [the artist]3491-the artist 's instinct before another , thought [she]183-joan had never looked so lovely as then . " Oh , [Mister Jan]241-mister jan , [you'm]0-i fond o '[0-i] [me]0-i ! " " Why , did n't [you]0-i know it , [Joan]183-joan ? Did it want [my]0-i words to tell [you]0-i so ? Had n't [you]0-i guessed it ? " [He]0-i rose slowly and approached [his]0-i picture . " Oh , how [I]0-i wish this was a little more like [my]0-i dream and like reality ! [I]0-i need inspiration , [Joan]183-joan ; [I]0-i have reached a point beyond which [I]0-i can not go . [My]0-i colors are dead ; [my]0-i soul is dead . A thing has come between [me]183-joan and [my]183-joan happiness , between [me]183-joan and [my]183-joan picture . [I]183-joan know not what to call it . [Nature]178-nature has sent it . " " Then '[183-joan] tis right an ' proper , [I]1533-my s'pose ? " " [I]1533-my suppose so , but it stops work . It makes [my]1533-my hand shake and [my]1533-my heart throb fast and [my]1533-my brains grow hot . " " Ca n't '[1533-my] [e]1533-my take no physic for't ? " " Why , yes , but [I]0-i hesitate . " [He]0-i turned to [her]183-joan and went close to [her]183-joan . " Let [me]0-i look at [you]183-joan , [Joan]183-joan — close — very close — so close that [I]0-i can feel [your]183-joan breath . It was so easy to learn the furze ; it is so hard to learn [you]183-joan . " " Sure [I]0-i 've comed out butivul in the picksher . " " Not yet , not yet . " [He]0-i put [his]0-i hands on [her]183-joan shoulders and looked into [her]183-joan eyes until [she]183-joan grew nervous and brushed [her]183-joan hand across [her]183-joan cheek . Then , without a second 's warning , [he]0-i bent down and kissed [her]183-joan on the mouth . " [Mister Jan]241-mister jan ! How could ' [e]183-joan ! '[0-i] Tis wrong — wrong of ' [e]183-joan ! [I]0-i 'd never a thot — " [She]183-joan started from [him]0-i , wild , alarmed , blushing hotly ; and [he]0-i shook [his]0-i head at [her]183-joan dismay and answered very calmly , very seriously : " It was not wrong , [Joan]183-joan , or [I]0-i should not have done it . [You]183-joan heard [me]0-i ask to whom [I]0-i should pray for inspiration , and [Nature]178-nature told [me]0-i [I]0-i must seek it from [you]183-joan . And [I]0-i have . " " [You]183-joan should n't never a done it . [I]0-i trusted '[0-i] [e]1534-e so ! " " But [I]0-i had to do it . [Nature]178-nature said ' Kiss [her]178-nature , and [you]183-joan will find what [you]183-joan want . '[178-nature] Do [you]0-i understand that ? [I]0-i have touched [you]0-i and [I]0-i am awake and alive again ; [I]0-i have touched [you]0-i , [Joan]183-joan , and [I]0-i am not hopeless and sad , but happy . [Nature]178-nature thought of [me]0-i , [Joan]183-joan , when [she]178-nature made [you]0-i and brought [you]0-i into [the world]3624-the world ; and [she]178-nature thought of [sweet Joan]183-joan when [she]178-nature fashioned [Jan.]196-mister jan. Believe it — [you]0-i must believe it . " " [You]0-i did ought to a arsked [me]0-i . " " Listen . [Nature]178-nature let [you]0-i live quiet in [the country]1536-the country — for [me]0-i , [Joan]183-joan . [She]178-nature let [me]0-i live all lonely in [the world]3624-the world — for [you]0-i . " " It is right and proper and fair and beautiful , " [he]196-mister jan. said quietly . " [My]1540-i heart sang when [I]1540-i kissed [you]0-i , [Joan]183-joan , and so did [yours]0-i . [D'you]4193-d'you know why ? Because [we]1538-we are two halves of a whole . Because the sunshine of [your]0-i life would go out without [me]1540-i ; because [my]1540-i life , which never had any sunshine in it until now , has been full of sunshine since [I]1540-i knew [Joan]183-joan . " " [I]1540-i dunnaw . '[1540-i] Twadden a proper thing to do , seein ' how [I]1540-i trusted '[1540-i] e. " " [We]1538-we are [children of Nature]1539-children of nature , [Joan]183-joan . [I]0-i always do what [she]1540-i tells [me]0-i . [I]0-i ca n't help it . [I]0-i have obeyed [her]1540-i all [my]0-i life . [She]1540-i tells [me]0-i to love [you]183-joan , [Joan]183-joan , and [I]0-i do . [I]0-i 'm very sorry . [I]1540-i thought [she]1540-i had told [you]183-joan to love [me]1540-i , but [I]1540-i suppose [I]1540-i was wrong . Never mind this once . Forgive [me]1540-i , [Joan]183-joan . [I]1540-i 'll even fight [Nature]178-nature rather than make [you]183-joan angry with [me]1540-i . Let [me]1540-i finish [my]1540-i picture and go away . Come . [I]1540-i 've no business to waste [your]183-joan precious time , though [you]183-joan have been so kind and generous with it . Only [I]1540-i was tired and hopeless and [you]183-joan came like a drink of wine to [me]1540-i , [Joan]183-joan ; and [I]1540-i drank too much , [I]1540-i suppose . " [He]1540-i picked up [his]1540-i brushes , spoke in a sad minor key , and seemed crushed and weary . The flash died from [his]1540-i face and [he]1540-i looked older again . [Joan]183-joan , [the mistress of the situation]4194-the mistress of the situation , found it wholly bitter . [She]183-joan was bewildered , for affairs had proceeded with such rapidity . [He]1540-i had declared frankly that [he]1540-i loved [her]183-joan , and yet had stopped there . To [her]183-joan ideas it was impossible that [a man]467-a man should say as much as that to [a woman]3541-a woman and no more . Love invariably meant ultimate union for life , [Joan]183-joan thought . [She]183-joan could not understand any other end to it . [The man]3494-the man talked about Nature as [a little child]4198-a little child talks of [[its]4198-a little child mother]4199-its mother . [He]3494-the man had deemed [himself]3494-the man entirely in the right ; yet something — not [Nature]178-nature , [she]183-joan supposed — had told [her]183-joan that [he]3494-the man was wrong . But who was [she]183-joan to judge [him]3494-the man ? Who was [she]183-joan to say where [his]3494-the man conduct erred ? [He]3494-the man loved truth . It was not a lie to kiss [a girl]491-a girl . [He]3494-the man promised nothing . How could [he]3494-the man promise anything or propose anything ? Was [she]183-joan not [[another man]1494-another man 's sweetheart]4202-another man 's sweetheart ? That doubtless had been the reason why [he]3494-the man had said no more than that [he]3494-the man loved [her]183-joan . To love [her]183-joan could be no sin . [Nature]178-nature had told [him]3494-the man to ; and [God]179-god knew how [she]183-joan loved [him]3494-the man now . But [she]183-joan could not make it up with [him]3494-the man . A cold curtain seemed to have fallen between [them]4203-them . The old reserve which had only melted after many meetings , was upon [him]3494-the man again . [He]3494-the man stood , as it seemed , on the former pedestal . A strange , surging sensation filled [her]183-joan head — a sense of helpless fighting against a flood of unhappy affairs . All the new glory of life was suddenly tarnished through [her]183-joan own act , and [she]183-joan felt that things could never be the same again . [She]183-joan thought and thought . Then [John Barron]176-barron saw [Joan]183-joan 's blue eyes begin to wink ominously , the corners of [her]183-joan bonny mouth drag down and something bright twinkle over [her]183-joan cheek . [He]176-barron took no notice , and when [he]176-barron looked up again , [she]183-joan had moved away and was sitting on the grass crying bitterly with [her]183-joan hands over [her]183-joan face . The sun was bright , a lark sang overhead ; from [adjacent inland fields]4204-adjacent inland fields came the jolt and clank of a plow with [a man]467-a man 's voice calling to [his]467-a man horses at the turns . [The artist]3491-the artist put down [his]3491-the artist palette and walked over to [Joan]183-joan . " [[My]1540-i dear]4088-my dear , [[my]1540-i dear]4088-my dear , " [he]1540-i said , " d'you know what 's making [you]183-joan so unhappy ? " [She]183-joan sobbed on and did not answer . " [I]1540-i can tell [you]183-joan , [I]1540-i think . [You]183-joan do n't quite know whether to believe [me]1540-i or not , [Joan]183-joan . That is very natural . Why should [you]183-joan believe [me]1540-i ? And yet if [you]183-joan knew — " [She]183-joan sat up , swallowed some of [her]183-joan tears , and smudged [her]183-joan face with [her]183-joan knuckles . [He]1540-i took a clean handkerchief from [his]1540-i pocket and handed it to [her]183-joan . It was cool and pleasant , and [she]183-joan went on crying a while , but tears which were comforting and different to the first stinging drops bred from a sudden , forlorn survey of life . [He]1540-i talked on , and [his]1540-i voice soothed [her]183-joan . [He]1540-i kept [his]1540-i distance , and presently , as [her]183-joan ruffled spirit grew calmer , [his]1540-i remarks assumed a brighter note . " Has [[my]1540-i poor little Lady of [the Gorse]563-the gorse]4209-my poor little lady of the gorse forgiven [me]1540-i at last ? [She]4209-my poor little lady of the gorse wo n't punish [me]1540-i any more , [I]1540-i know , and it is a very terrible punishment to see tears in [her]4209-my poor little lady of the gorse eyes . " Then [she]183-joan found [her]183-joan tongue again and words to answer [him]1540-i , together with fluttering sighs that told the tears were ended . " [I]1540-i dunnaw why for [I]1540-i cried , [Mr. Jan]241-mister jan , but [I]1540-i seemed '[1540-i] mazed like .
